Review title: A very different sort of film for Hanks.
Review_body: The plot to "News of the World" is pretty simple and it's a leisurely paced film...somewhat like Clint Eastwood's "Cry Macho". It is set in 1870 in the Reconstruction Era in Texas. Captain Kidd (Tom Hanks) is a Civil War veteran who happens upon a head man and a wild blonde girl in the wilderness. There are papers with the dead man's possessions indicating that the girl, Johanna, was abducted and raised by Kiowa Indians after her parents were killed. She was discovered with the Kiowa and the US Army sent her with an agent to return her to her extended family. But he's dead...and no one seems willing to help...so Kidd finally agrees to take her the 400 miles to Castroville, Texas (near San Antonio).As you'd suspect, this won't be easy since the child really wants to be with the Kiowa and she doesn't understand English. Her family were German immigrants...so she understands some German...but Kidd only knows a few words of the language himself. The film shows them on their journey across the Plains to her family.This is a most enjoyable film and a nice change of pace for Tom Hanks. It also talks about a seldom discussed problem which happened on rare occasions...white kids being abducted and raised by various tribes. Interesting and never dull.

A good old-fashioned western from director Paul Greengrass, better than his last, the morbid 22 JULY. This one adopts a traditional journey narrative in its story of a grizzled Tom Hanks transporting a precocious young girl across the hostile West in search of her estranged family members. The news aspect doesn't really add much to the story, but Greengrass's superior direction is what makes this worth a watch. He brings in the suspense, handling it well in a lengthy set-piece in which limited firepower adds to the tension. Hanks is on form here and the whole thing is engaging, if not spectacular.

It's 1870. Former confederate soldier Captain Kidd (Tom Hanks) travels from town to town reading the newspapers for a paying audience. On the road, he comes across a lynched black man and a little white girl (Helena Zengel). She's a Kiowa child who apparently was taken from settlers many years ago. Kidd is forced to take the child back to her surviving family.Director Paul Greengrass is doing a John Ford western. It's sort of like The Searchers. Tom Hanks is doing his everyman. The little girl is terrific. They have good chemistry together. It's a very simple road movie. It's all good... except for Greengrass standard shaky cam style. It doesn't really fit the genre. He needs a tripod. There are a few scenes that need some work but mostly it's the shaky cam.

Review title: My First Movie In A Theater In Ten Months Was A Good One
Review_body: Tom Hanks travels around Texas, reading newspapers from near and far to people who are to busy and too tired to do so for themselves. They pay a dime a head -- big money in Reconstruction Texas, with Federal troops on everyone's neck, fear of Kiowas, Blacks and Mexicans to people in charge. Hanks just goes about, reading, never dealing with the fact that he was a captain in the 3rd Texas Infantry, or the wife he hasn't seen in at least half a dozen years.One day on the road, he finds a hanged Kiowa with a badly-printed placard. He also finds Helena Zengel, whose parents were killed, and her carried off by the Indians, so long ago she only speaks Kiowa. No one in authority wants to deal with her, so Hanks finds himself toting her along until he can drop her off at her aunt's farm.Along the way, of course, they have adventures. I had the impression I was looking at a late 1960s A western, with Jimmy Stewart -- this is Tom Hanks, after all -- instead of John Wayne. There's even a role for Bruce Dern essayed by Michael Angelo Covino. I admired the way that Paul Greengrass's direction allowed character to be revealed gradually, and Dariusz Wolski's camerawork, always ugly, always fascinating, a world of brown dust. Tom Hanks plays decent, but wounded, and Miss Zengel seems to have based her performance on Patty Duke's in THE MIRACLE WORKER.

Review title: Interesting watch for the most part, even if real greatness is never achieved
Review_body: "News of the World" is a relatively new movie that I got to watch in an outdoor cinema last night and I would like to share my thoughts now . The director of these minimally under two hours is the established Oscar-nominated filmmaker Paul Greengrass and this is not the first time he has worked with Oscar-winning actor Tom Hanks. He is of course the man you see on the photo here on imdb. And also not the first time in which the key supporting play garners much more awards attention than Hanks himself, even if it is a little girl. Back then, it was Barkhad Abdi (to an even bigger extent) and these two at least have the international background in common, even if it is entirely different regions of the world. Or look at Mark Rylance and how things went there. Definitely not a bad time to star alongside Hanks in a motion picture. For me, this one here was of course particularly interesting because the girl on the poster here on imdb is Helena Zengel who just had her big breakthrough with the film Systemsprenger not too long ago and immediately afterwards managed to get the role here and also make big waves internationally because she was nominated for an SAG Award (so recognized by her peers, kinda unreal in this context) and nominated for a Golden Globe as well. Shay may have missed out on the BAFTA nomination and eventually, more "tragically", on the Oscar nomination too, but still a super successful year for her. I must say that very early on in this movie here I was definitely reminded of Systemsprenger (I think the English title is "System crasher"?) with her angry running around and screaming and even biting once it felt like something that could exactly have come this way from the character she played in the German movie. And honestly if we forget the different backgrounds, actors and locations for a second here, then this could almost be a sequel with Hanks' character finally managing to tame her what Schuch's couldn't. Anyway, enough of that now as those who haven#t see Systemsprenger or don't even know about it are certainly still the majority here and have no clue what I am talking about.As for Zengel, it can still be said that the role also suited her in terms of the character because she played an Indian girl with German background, so she speaks a few word Indian language there and very few German and English only, so no problem that she is maybe not super fluent in English. She didn't have to be. It was all about her physical presence basically and there surely is a lot there and I think she was a good casting decision, even if maybe the awards recognition was too much. The one really light moment, namely when her character discovers the taste of sugar, was very nice and memorable too. I still think Hanks and his performance should not have been ignore entirely the way they were by awards bodies mostly. He was pretty commanding as always, hit all the right notes and was the epitome of a lead performance really carrying the film from beginning to end. He did fine with the action sequence, there is some gunfire here with the western background for example on some occasions, but also the emotional sequences like when he finally manages to really say farewell to his wife (she was pretty young no?) and find closure there, so you could say that somehow he is ready for a new woman in his life by his side, even if it is just a girl and something like a father-daughter relationship. The subject of belonging was key here with nobody really ready to take the girl. Early on, the friends of the male protagonist she runs away from. Before the film starts, her people were killed even. Near the end, the Indians in the sandstorm were also not ready to keep her. I actually thought this was a Fata Morgana initially, but I guess the fact that they gave her a horse made it real. And in the end, there are of course those who basically treat her like a dog and tier her up, so she cannot run away and are also angry because she doesn't work. But the grave story at the very end with the knocking parts was some really cute closure.In general, I think this film worked nicely as a modern western. I'd also have liked to see Jeff Bridges or maybe even Mickey Rourke play Hanks' character. The ways in which all the dangers were depicted was also handled with competence. This include savage former soldiers driven by their genitals basically and the unspeakable things they want to do to the little girl and the officers there cannot really protect them, just give them a headstart. But this segment with Hanks' and Zengel's characters really working together as a team to save each other was nicely done. Also no pseudo drama with the leader of the guys not being dead initially or something. He gets the full load and is gone immediately. It was almost kinda positive waiting when we see his final aide run into doom with the bullets being real bullets and not just stuff to shoot birds. Okay, maybe the leader making this statement exactly there felt a bit too scripted. Then we have the other gang of bad guys, many more whose leader wants Hanks to support his leadership with fake news if you want to call it that, but there it was depicted in a convincing manner (maybe too fast) how information can raiise questioning and own judgment. It was still good, also the crucial moment in which the simple fella from earlier shows up and takes revenge for his brother and saves our heroes' lives this way. I still think a little less political correctness would have been nice here and there and the movie felt slightly too much as if wanted to please the mainstream media. One of not many criticisms I have here. There wasother than that just one quote I did not like, namely when Hanks' character tells Zengel's that they both have their own demons to face on this journey. That did feel a bit scripted and for the sake of it.Then again, it is all scripted as this was done by Greengrass himself with the help of Oscar nominee Paul Davies and the original novel is by Paulette Jiles. Apparently, this is her second writing effort that got turned into a movie and the first happened over 40 years ago and she played a little role in that movie back then even it seems and is still alive today. Well, no small role this time, but I am sure she can be happy about the outcome. Apart from the dangers through vile humans (this is set back in the days when racism was still a big thing in America, actually was, and not just stirred up, namely when it got closer towards the end of North vs. South back then), we also see how dangerous nature can be. Be it the horse going crazy on one occasion and almost killing them if they hadn't jumped of the thingey right on time, or be it the lack of water or be it the gigantic sand storm coming up on one occasions. You sure need a man like Hanks' character, former soldier to goide you through these challenges and he does so with dignity. He is almost too perfect of a character you could say overall. Maybe that is the reason why he never really scores acting nominations anymore. There are not enough shades and he is just the nicest guy ever, but still on the tough side. The best example was the other fella back when Hanks was home again who told him repeatedly that he could not have done anything.Okay, that is it then. This is a really good watch for everybody who likes Hanks and who is not opposed to western movies. Why would anyone be? It's an amazing genre for sure. Also German who care about Zengel's progress can definitely give it a go. But it is also good from every other perspective. It does not drag, which is quite impressive given the fairly massive running time, like almost never let's say. The writing is competent (cannot compare it to the book as I have not read the latter) and the acting is especially top-notch, maybe the film's biggest strength. Down to really small characters like the two the girl stays with temporarily at the end. Thomas Francis Murphy deserves a crucial mention as well as he did so much with not that much screen time. Massive thumbs-up and I also liked how his character is also a criminal of course, but at the same time a victim of the circumstances and the racist world he was born into. A leader for the dark side as a consequence in contrast to our hero. So don't be fooled into thinking that nobody except Hanks is famous here and therefore the cast is maybe not good. The opposite is the case. A prime example of how big names are not key for a good movie. Of course, also could have had to do with them really not wanting to take any attention away from Tom, which is maybe not the best approach, bit still it all turned out right in the end. The only question here is if it is a good or great film. The positive recommendation is never in doubt. Right now, I will go with "good film". Maybe another two stars on rewatch at some point. We will see. In any case, do not miss out on this one, preferrably watch on the big screen because those visual and audible components that scored Oscar nominations there are much easier to enjoy at your local cinema than on a small computer screen. But as long as you watch it, it's all good.

Captain Kidd (Tom Hanks) fought in the Civil War for Texas. He lost his wife and business during the war and has moved on, reading newspapers in small towns though out Texas. Along the way he finds a little girl stranded. She is a white girl raised by the Kiowa Native Americans. He tasks himself with taking her to her uncle and aunt. They get attached along the way through various adventures of danger and peril facing bigotry.All in all it was a heart warming tale. You couldn't help but be taken in by Helena Zengel.Guide: No swearing, sex, or nudity.

In the good old days, this probably would have been made with John Wayne in the main role. And who wouldn't want to star in a movie that has that John Wayne feeling all along? I think Tom Hanks liked the idea as well he should. Add to that the German Wunderkind from "Systemsprenger" and you have a duo that seems to be made for each other.At first the young girl seems to reprise her angry alter ego from that other movie, but her character here is richer, even if the shades remain to a degree (for different reasons of course). The movie moves along at a nice pace and has everything a classic Western should have. Shootouts included - and an ending that is predictable but nonetheless emotional!

It seems most great actors eventually get around to doing a Western. You can go all the way back to Bogart and Cagney, heck, they even did one together called "The Oklahoma Kid". I could be wrong, but I don't think Tom Hanks has appeared in one before, a quick scan of his credits here on IMDb seems to suggest that he hasn't. So he gets his turn in "News of the World", and he does a fine job escorting a young girl of German background back to her relatives, after her parents were massacred by a band of Kiowa Indians, and raised as one of them. There did seem to be a disconnect in the story whereby Captain Jefferson Kyle Kidd (Hanks) refers to a document he comes across identifying the scared youth as Johanna Leonberger (Helena Zengel). I'm unclear how he was able to make that connection; it seemed more like wish fulfillment than actual fact. Especially since 'Cicada's' time with the Kiowa seemed to be fairly lengthy, long enough to forget how to speak her native language and consider herself the daughter of Turning Water and Third Spotted.The wandering pair wind up in a handful of typical Western scenarios, dodging outlaws on the trail and in Kidd's case, inciting a near riot in the town of Erath. When I first heard this picture's title, I couldn't make sense of how it related to the story, but as it turns out, Kidd's occupation following the Civil War was traveling from town to town and reading the headline articles to each location's citizens for the fee of a dime. In Erath, Kidd cleverly relates the story of a Pennsylvania town that rose up against the rich owners of a coal mine who took advantage of their employees' poverty and lack of education. Johanna proves useful in several situations where by her observations and her wits, helps Kidd overcome the obstacles he comes face to face with.Though the resolution of the story is fairly predictable, it still manages to well up a heartfelt acknowledgment that Captain Kidd was no pirate, but a decent man who's loss of wife to cholera during the war finds a measure of relief by taking Johanna in as his ward and educating her to a new life on the road as an accompanist to his readings. The feel good ending is made more satisfying by Johanna's smiling face, as she pounds out the beat of a humorous story Kidd relates to his latest group of listeners.

Not to be confused with the tabloid newspaper that ceased publication in 2011, I saw the leading actor talking about this film on The Graham Norton Show, and when it was nominated during Awards Season, I was up for it, directed by Paul Greengrass (United 93, The Bourne Ultimatum, Captain Phillips). Basically, set in 1870, Captain Jefferson Kyle Kidd (Tom Hanks) is a former member of the Confederate Army who served in the 3rd Texas Infantry. Five years after the end of the Civil War, Kidd makes a living traveling town to town as a non-fiction storyteller. He reads the newspaper headlines about presidents and royalty, glorious feuds, devastating catastrophes, and gripping adventures from around the world to townspeople (most illiterate) for ten cents per person. Following an evening of news reading, setting out for his next location, Kidd finds an overturned wagon at the side of the road. Investigating, he finds the body of a black soldier and a young white girl (Golden Globe nominated Helena Zengel), dressed in Native American clothing and speaking in the Kiowa language. After an encounter with a Union Army patrol, Kidd is instructed to take the girl to Union officials at a checkpoint in a town up the road where they will sort out her Bureau of Indian Affairs paperwork and return her to her surviving family. Kidd reluctantly agrees to the request. At the checkpoint Kidd is informed that the Bureau of Indian Affairs representative will not be available for three months. Travelling to the next town, Kidd reads the news and seeks shelters with a former Confederate infantryman. After returning to the ten-year-old girl, whom he names Johanna (her real name is Cicada), he begrudgingly accepts responsibility for taking her to her surviving family. As they set out, they have difficulty communicating. Johanna was taken in by the Kiowa people six years earlier and raised as one of their own, so cannot speak English. During the journey, Kidd is confronted by three ex-Confederate soldiers turned criminals who try to purchase the girl from Kidd. He refuses, but the three men pursue, leading to a shootout in the wilderness during which Johanna and Kidd learn to work together to survive. They next encounter a radical band of militia working to "cleanse" the county from "outsiders". Kidd is told to read the approved news from the town's leader, but instead reads about a group of coal miners who rally against the man responsible for putting their lives in jeopardy. Kidd's story incites civil unrest, and ultimately results in Johanna gunning down the town's leader and rescuing Kidd. After this, Kidd and Johanna initially join a wagon train bound for the railroad line. They eventually veer off to locate Johanna's surviving family. During the journey, the wagon suffers an accident, going at high speed and unable to brake, Kidd and Johanna are forced to jump from the wagon, which crashes and is destroyed. The pair are forced to continue on foot through the heat of the desert, until they are found and rescued by a group of Kiowa. Johanna communicates with them and is able to obtain a horse. Kidd and Johanna eventually reach the farm of her aunt and uncle, the former revealing that Johanna's parents left to make it on their own and moved to hill country where the land is cheaper. They killed in a Kiowa raid. Kidd reluctantly leaves Johanna with them and returns to San Antonio. His wife, Maria Luisa Betancourt Kidd, died from cholera in 1865. He visits the mission where she is buried, and mournfully leaves his wedding ring and a locket on her grave. Kidd then rides back to the village where he left Johanna, where he finds her tied to a pole. Her aunt and uncle explain that she incontrollable, refusing to work and constantly running off. Asking forgiveness, Kidd tells Johanna (in Kiowa) that she belongs with him. Johanna accepts his apology and her aunt and uncle let them go. The last scene sees Kidd reading the papers in another town, with Johanna helping by making sound effects, and bearing a new name: Johanna Kidd. Also starring Thomas Francis Murphy as Farley, Elizabeth Marvel as Ella Gannett, Mare Winningham as Doris Boudlin, Ray McKinnon as Simon Boudlin, Neil Sandilands as Wilhelm Leonberger, Chukwudi Iwuji as Charles Edgefield, and Bill Camp as Willie Branholme. Hanks gives a good reserved and thoughtful performance, and Zengel proves a good young upcoming star as the mute child, this works well as both traditional of the genre and as a road movie, with exciting rocky shootout sequences, treacherous plains, and sweeping landscapes, it looks great and is engaging, a worthwhile western drama. It was nominated the Oscars for Best Sound, Best Production Design, Best Original Score for James Newton Howard, and Best Cinematography, it was nominated the BAFTAs for Best Sound, Best Production Design, Best Cinematography, and Original Score, and it was nominated the Golden Globe for Best Original Score. Very good!

For some reason then I have been putting watching the 2020 movie "News of the World" off until now in 2021. But I finally got around to watching it. And I must admit that I had been missing out on a good cinematic experience.This being a movie with Tom Hanks in the lead, chances were that the movie would be great. And truthfully so, "News of the World" was indeed a good movie. I happened to enjoy the storyline and the Western setting in which the story took place.The story told in "News of the World", as written by Paul Greengrass and Luke Davies was a story that quickly captured my interest and the progression of the story was well-paced. And the story was well brought to life with an interesting character gallery as well. So the writers definitely managed to come up with something wholeheartedly entertaining here.This 2020 movie is a nice addition to the Western genre, without it actually being an archetypical Western. So that was something that I certainly enjoyed about the movie.The actors and actresses in the movie were definitely nicely cast. Needless to say that having Tom Hanks in the lead as Captain Kidd was a great choice, and he really carried the movie quite well with his performance. And while I am not familiar with actress Helena Zengel, but she put on a good performance as well and really acted nicely opposite of veteran actor Tom Hanks.I am glad that I opted to sit down and watch director Paul Greengrass' 2020 movie, because it was definitely an enjoyable movie.My rating of "News of the World" lands on a six out of ten stars.

This is so totally familiar and you know pretty much where it's headed. But that's a comfort sometimes of such movies like these, and the pleasure is how it's done - and Tom Hanks as Captain Kidd when he goes back to that town he's from and sees his friend and most especially visits his wife's grave is a solid reminder why he can so powerfully channel deep reservoirs of feeling (and in a different key than in his last time with Greengrass at the end of Captain Phillips, but no less true) - and in the details of how this man and young girl survive in the elements of the deserts of Texas. And it's one of the only Westerns I can think of that makes paramount the idea of education and communication what binds us and strengthens human connection. News of the World is a comforting blanket of a movie, and nice to experience (if you can) in a theater.I'll be a corny pile of stuff for a second (maybe it's also from doing driving instruction the past several months and having to learn how to speak with Spanish language students), but I think discovery and deepening understanding is what will make us last as a civilization. And if there's any real "villain" in this movie it's anti-intellectualism (also captivating given the genre), and the concept of people who are others as their proprerty. We get that with the fifteen minutes this becomes the most conventional part, though still thrilling and well shot and edited by Greengrass and company (and thank god he's calmed down on the hand-held) as Not Casey Affleck (seriously the dude sounds just like him) and his gang try to take the girl by force, and with that one Would-be Badass-But-Really-Loser in that town who would shoot you dead for not reading his own propaganda.And, again, a lot of this rests on Hanks and his underrated ability to do so much with a look, or a series of looks. And Zengel gives as good as he does.

Review title: OK BUT NOT-NEWS...A TAKE-NO CHANCES...FAMILY-FRIENDLY WESTERN...A ROAD TRIP WITH 2 LOST BUT GOOD SOULS
Review_body: Solid if Safe Western, Tom Hanks 1st (Sheriff Woody doesn't count).Nothing that has Not been Seen Before.Well Crafted Post-Civil War Character Study of 2 Lost Souls in a Land where it is Easy to Get Lost in the Expanse of the New World's Open Spaces.Easy Describes this Tale of a Moving News-Dealer, Selling HIs "Town Crier" Wares for One-Thin-Dime, the 10th of a Dollar, that can be Used in Shot-Gun Casing Filler in a Pinch.A Scene Depicting just That, Showcases the Kid Traveling Companion for Captain Kidd,as a Resourceful, Hardened Little 12 Year Old, that the Gruffy Civil-War Vet and Heard-it-All, Absorber of Headlines,Discovers that She is a Hidden-Gem Among the Rocks and Snakes Crawling About.She is a Foreign-Born Actress, Helena Zengel, who Brings Her Own Screen-Presence to the Show and Holds Her Own with a Big Movie-Star, the Ever Likeable Hanks.Maybe Someday the Actor may Stretch and Play Someone Evil or Truly Villainous, but it's Definitely Not in this Movie that Doesn't Stretch Anything.It's a Ride that Feels Comfortable Despite the Dirt Roads and Rickety Buckboard, that has an Occasional Human Obstacle to Contend.In the End it's a Mild Diversion.This Exploration of Life in the "Land of Opportunity", circa 1870 Texas and its Racist Rumblings,is Destined for its Place Among the Tall-Tale a sort of Bed-Time Story that is Suitable for the Family's Young Ones.As Feel-Good as it Gets in these Cynical Times.

"Captain Phillips" director Paul Greengrass casts Tom Hanks in his first western "News of the World" as a gray-bearded Civil War veteran who rides through Northern Texas and reads newspapers to audiences willing to pay ten cents. Strictly speaking, he isn't the equivalent of a contemporary newscaster. Instead, he's more like those who read books for the benefit of the blind. A former officer in the Confederate Army, Captain Jefferson Kyle Kidd served with the Third Texas Infantry, and he has the wounds to prove it. Sadly, Kidd's Maria wife died during the war from cholera, and our sexagenarian protagonist has embarked on a new occupation which heralds his gift of oratory. He leads a lonely existence, with friends scattered along dusty trails hither and yon. Kidd's routine is turned upside down when he encounters an abandoned, 10-year-old girl running loose in the wilderness. The black trooper assigned to escort her to an Army relocation camp has been lynched. The sign on his chest reads: "Texas Says No! This is White Man's Country." The daughter of German immigrants whose mother, father, and sister were butchered by ferocious Kiowa Indians, Johanna (newcomer Helena Zengel) has nowhere to run. Ironically, she identifies more with her former captors. She speaks a mishmash of Kiowa and German, and Kidd struggles to develop her English language speaking skills. Greengrass and Oscar nominated co-scripter Luke Davies of "Lion" have adapted Paulette Jiles' marvelous bestselling novel "News of the World," but they cannot rival her splendid prose and penchant for obscure detail. Once she joins up with Kidd, Johanna travels 400 miles with the old timer as he searches for her Teutonic kin. They survive a number of incidents, some more exciting than others. Hanks' sterling performance, a weather-beaten supporting cast, authentic looking Old West towns, and "Dark City" lenser Dariusz Wolski's atmospheric photography cannot offset the monotony that undermines this character-driven, PG-13 rated sagebrusher. Western buffs may gripe about the shortage of shootouts, but Tom Hanks fans should relish watching him ride tall in the saddle.
Although it takes place during the 1870s on the Texas frontier, "News of the World" doesn't qualify as a traditional John Wayne western. The Duke did make one offbeat genre classic "The Searchers" (1956), with acclaimed superstar director John Ford, about a racist troubleshooter who rescued his niece from captivity among the Indians. Ironically, he had vowed to kill her if he found the Indians had brainwashed her. Captain Jefferson Kyle Kidd emerges as far less complicated than Wayne's Ethan Edwards in "The Searchers." A widower who published a newspaper before the war, Kidd is a dutiful but decent fellow who hasn't reconciled himself with his wife's death. Nevertheless, he ushers little Johanna as far as an Army station. The officer-in-charge notifies him that the Indian Agent who handles strays won't be back for three months. Not for an instant does Kidd consider leaving the ten-year old to fend for herself around a notorious Army fort for any length of time. He decides to take the child to the agent himself. Along the way, Johanna and he forge a sense of respect and trust between them. Essentially, "News of the World" amounts to a scenic road trip, a journey of hardship where adversity peels back layer upon layers to expose both protagonists and antagonists. "The Searchers" dealt with adults. Comparably, "News of the World" recalls another Wayne horse opera, "True Grit" (1969). Cantankerous Marshal Rooster Cogburn (Wayne) took a precocious female teen on a ride through Hades in search of her father's cowardly killer. The tweener in "News of the World" also reminded me of the munchkin with whom crusty Gregory Peck found himself saddled in "Shoot Out" (1971) after Peck got out of prison and aims to payback the dastard who double-crossed him. Although Hanks doesn't play an invincible, larger-than-life man of action like either Wayne or Peck, his Jefferson Kyle Kidd fought in the American Civil War, and he is inclined to kill anybody who threatens their lives.
If you've seen enough classic westerns, the revelations in "News of the World" won't surprise you. Twice during their odyssey Kidd and Johanna tangle with obnoxious ruffians ready to kill them, while the remainder are made up of bland, non-violent moments. Alongside these two attempts on their lives, our protagonists survive a rollercoaster ride down a winding trail in a runaway wagon. The careening wagon out of control is about as exciting as this 118-minute movie gets when our hero and heroine aren't being used for target practice. Meantime, "News of the World" relies heavily on the surefire romance formula of opposites who attract. Eventually, as they shed their mutual suspicion, the two grow accustomed to each other. Initially, Johanna keeps Kidd at arms' length. By fadeout, however, she has thawed out and responds with warmth to her benefactor. Greengrass and company generate considerable tension with the depiction of ornery Texans who abhor the Union. Texas smoldered with anarchy during the post-war Era of Reconstruction. Indeed, an occupation Army of heavily-armed Union soldiers-derided as "blue bellies" by the locals--prowled the towns and halted the natives to scrutinize their loyalty oaths. Meantime, like some of John Wayne's later westerns in the 1960s, "News of the World" boasts one suspenseful gunfight that solidifies with surprising results the friendship between Kidd and Johana. Three low-down, no-account, ex-Confederate soldiers insist on buying Johanna, and these varmints refuse "no" for an answer. Instead of standing up to them, Kidd flees from them, lashing his horse relentlessly into a gallop. Careening his rickety wagon frantically through rough country, our hero doesn't outrun these hellions for long, and a cat & mouse shootout ensues. Altogether, the memorable scenes in "News of the World" never outnumber the mediocre ones. Altogether, Paulette Jiles' evocative prose in her novel lingers long after the film's stunning drone visuals fade away.

Is it possible for a film to be too topical?Yes, when it's a western set in 1870 that tries as obviously as this one does to draw parallels to the world we live in in 2021. It's like the folks who made this movie were given a checklist of every single issue that's raised its ugly head over the last four years of our recent crappy history and decided that every one of them had to be shoehorned into the film somehow. I get it, the problems we have today are descended from problems that existed coming out of the American Civil War. I don't disagree, but there has to be a more nuanced approach to that idea than the one this movie takes.And I just really wasn't in the mood for a bunch of toxic white males acting like horrid human beings. I get enough of that in the news every day.This movie is at its best when Tom Hanks and the marvelous Helena Zengel share their bonding moments, but those moments are few and are overshadowed by scenes of horrible Texans doing bad things to just about everybody. I'm getting very tired of movies that have me rooting for awful things to happen to bad guys because of how monstrous they are.If movie award precursors are any indication, Zengel came within a hair's breadth of being nominated for an Oscar for this film, and it would have been deserved. She's the best thing about it.Grade: B.

Greetings again from the darkness. Even in the midst of a pandemic, December is Oscar-qualifying time. And that means we get Tom Hanks' latest movie. This time out, the two-time Oscar winner reunites with his CAPTAIN PHILLIPS (2013) director Paul Greengrass (three "Bourne" movies, and Oscar nominated for UNITED 93, 2006) for Hanks' first ride into the western genre. Luke Davies (Oscar nominated for LION, 2016) adapted the screenplay from Paulette Jiles' 2016 novel.The beloved Mr. Hanks stars as Captain Jefferson Kyle Kidd. We know his full name because he proudly announces it at each stop of his news-reading route. That's right, even in 1870, which is before television and radio and internet, a person could earn a living reading the news. OK, so it wasn't the millions that national anchors make these days, as he was dependent on the audience dropping a coin or two in the tin cup. For this they were treated to Captain Kidd's robust presentation of news and events (and some gossip) from around the nation ... straight from the news clippings he collected during his travels.On the trail one day, Captain Kidd comes across a horrific scene of violence, and a 10 year old girl with a shock of blonde hair. She only speaks Kiowa, but the found paperwork lists her name as Johanna (the first American film for Helena Zengel). It turns out, tragic events in her family's home many years earlier left Johanna being raised by the Kiowa Indians. Captain Kidd is now on a mission to return her to her surviving relatives (an aunt and uncle), but there are at least three obstacles to his plan: it's a rigorous trip of about 400 miles, the girl doesn't want to go, and there remains much tension in the split among the post-war citizenry. So what we have here is a western road trip (trail ride) that's a blend of TRUE GRIT (minus the witty banter) and THE SEARCHERS.It should be noted that Captain Jefferson Kyle Kidd has served in three wars, including the recently concluded Civil War. He may make his living wearing bifocals and reading newspapers, but Kidd is no nerd. He handles pressure quite naturally, as we witness in chase scene up a rocky hill. The resulting shootout not only creates the first bond between Kidd and Johanna, but also flashes the Captain's calming influence. This is a soulful and principled Tom Hanks (as usual), but this time he's riding a horse and his furrowed brow is working overtime.The trip to Johanna's home coincidentally takes Kidd very close to where he once lived - a place that holds his best and worst memories. As viewers we see what Captain Kidd and Johanna don't. They are both headed back to a past they no longer belong to. Along the way, the two travelers cross paths with characters played by Elizabeth Marvel, Ray McKinnon, Mare Winningham, and the always great Bill Camp. There is nothing rushed about the story or these people. Fans of director Greengrass will be surprised to find an absence of his trademark rapid-cut action sequences, but he has delivered a sweeping epic with superb cinematography (Dariusz Wolski, "Pirates of the Caribbean" franchise), expert editing (Oscar winner William Goldenberg, ARGO), and a terrific score (8-time Oscar nominee James Newton Howard). Mr. Hanks delivers yet another stellar performance (of course), and young Ms. Zengel's assured performance likely means we will be treated to her work for years to come. It's a quasi-western period piece that is plenty interesting to watch, yet lacks the memorable moments to justify multiple watches or a place among the genre's best.
Opens December 25, 2020

Review title: A snapshot of post Civil War America
Review_body: Tom Hanks has made a career out of playing kind and reasonable men and this film is not an exception. Set right after the Civil War, the movie shows the story of an ex captain in the Southern Army who now lives by travelling from city to city and reading the news of faraway newspapers. He finds an orphan girl who is blonde but only speaks Kiowa and takes her on a trip to her natural German family. Themes of human kindness, racism, the evils of civilization and "Texas says no!" are lightly touched as we explore the desolate landscape of the southern Unites States.Now, the film is a bit slow. There are about five major things that happen in the entire film, which makes it feel a bit like a collection of anecdotes than a single story. Based on Paulette Jiles' novel with the same name from 2016.Bottom line: it's not an action flick. You have to give in to the rhythm of the story in order to enjoy it. The acting is good, the landscape shots really beautiful and overall it's an informative movie that reminds us where the U.S. came from, while asking the viewer to consider where it is going, and also without being heavy handed in any way.

Review title: Slow burning, but ultimately rewarding yarn
Review_body: STAR RATING: ***** Saturday Night **** Friday Night *** Friday Morning ** Sunday Night * Monday MorningCaptain Kidd (Tom Hanks) is a civil war veteran, scarred and haunted by the events that went on. He now travels from town to town, relaying world events to rapturous audiences who lap up his oratory style. However, things take an unexpected turn when he discovers Johanna (Helena Zengel) a young girl hiding in his carriage, who was abducted by Indians. Kidd makes it his mission to reunite Johanna with her parents, and, on the way, is forced to come to terms with his own demons.To a British audience, at least, at first glance the title News of the World, promised a scintillating glance into the goings on at the now defunct trashy tabloid and its eventual well earned downfall. Given Paul Greengrass's close up, realist style, that might have felt more like his natural habitat, as the outback setting at first glance doesn't feel like fitting terrain in this second collaboration with Tom Hanks after 2013's Captain Phillips, but it gradually manages to build in to something rewarding.It suffers from a dull opening, meandering and not really holding your attention in the right way, and requires your patience to stick with it, but it slowly develops in to something more engaging, forming the right sense of atmosphere and mood, and manages to draw you in. Hanks is reliably commanding in a role like this which he always does so well, and his young co star Zengel is also impressive as a near mute girl whose trust Kidd has to wean. Taking up most of the film's screen time together, they thankfully create an endearing bond.It struggles to find its way at first but, like it's two protagonists, eventually manages to find its way and work with its charge. ***

Part of the sub-genre in which an older man has to escort a young child to safety, Paul Greengrass' latest effort is probably his least 'Paul Greengrassy' to date. 'News Of The World (2020)' doesn't feature an abundance of close-up cinematography, fast-paced action, shaky camerawork or chaotic tension. Instead, it's a slow-burning western with subtle but significant character work and a somewhat unbiased approach to its time-period, portraying the differing forms of racism - including the destruction of the Native American people - without ever really flinching. However, it isn't exactly an unflinching examination of American prejudice; these elements are simply treated as part of the landscape. That's not necessarily a bad thing, as it allows for the story to take place in a more realistic representation of the period in which it's set. It does almost feel like a bit of a missed opportunity, though, because the movie doesn't really say anything about these issues. It also doesn't really say anything about the complex history of the young girl at its centre, who was stolen by some Kiowa people just after her family moved to the US from Germany and is now "an orphan twice over". It's constantly on the brink of making a potent point about the definition of heritage and family, but it never quite does. Still, the effort is appreciated. Plus, the relationship between the two leads does evolve nicely - if quietly - over the course of the film, leading to an expected but satisfying finale. Perhaps the affair's stand-out scene is an elongated and suspenseful shootout that sees Hanks' aging captain stand off against three would-be child-traffickers with only a handful of bullets and bit of birdshot. It's a great scene that makes excellent use of its environment. Another high point is a moody and atmospheric sequence in which the protagonist pair are forced to do a news reading (which is the captain's profession) in a dangerous, buffalo-hunting, backwards-thinking town. In general, the film is enjoyable and engaging. It is fairly slowly paced, though, especially during its first act. It's also only ever so compelling, an issue that's difficult to describe but certainly contributes to the flick's overall quality. Even though its plot is very straightforward, it's a solid western that focuses more on character than anything else. 6/10.

As much as I enjoy Tom Hanks reading old-timey newspapers and contemplating the barren landscapes of a road trip, "News of the World" is lackluster for not much else going on for its two hours. The Western tale of a father-daughter relationship is uninspired. It hardly even echoes "The Searchers" (1956). And if Paul Greengrass and company were going for some sort of political commentary regarding the fake news of one town's so-called newspaper or the even blander historical admission of America's Civil War, lynching and genocide it fails. But, it's a nice-looking picture, and, yeah, I don't mind spending time listening to Hanks read. The man's a national--nay--world treasure.Of more potential, though, was the notion of a traveling storyteller as the protagonist. A nation torn apart, put back together again through a grand narrative of stories selected by this itinerant exhibitor of the nation's newsprint. "News of the World" doesn't demonstrate that, though. This is a fractured and violent world that's depicted, and a capricious one that may strike people down otherwise with contagion (cholera in this case). Hanks adopting a kid hardly rectifies that. Not that I expected a connection to be made in the movie, but I also think it's worth noting that this is largely how movies began and as based, if not necessarily on the newspaper variety, of showmen circulating other entertainments and novelties. At the turn of the century afore, cinema was introduced to Americans and the rest of the world by exhibitors going from village to city, fairground to opera house, assembling pieces of footage from various filmmakers and studios from all over and often adding their own narration to produce an evening's entertainment.

Review title: Beautiful touching film of a child "lost" between two worlds and the gentleman who meetss her
Review_body: In post Civil War Texas, Captain Jefferson Kidd wanders from town to town reading the news of the country and the world to folks who can't read. Its a tent gathering, with everyone paying a dime to learn and to be entertained with Kidd's winning style. In truth, Kidd is a lost soul who has horrific memories of the war and the wife he left behind in San Antonio. One day, after a performance in North Texas, Kidd enters a woods and finds a child left on her own; her escort is dead nearby. This is Johanna (Helena Zengel) , once a child of German immigrants in Texas but captive four years with the Kiowa Native Americans. She calls herself Cicada and only speaks her adopted language, although she has papers which identify her. Most of all, she wants to return to the Kiowa but the US Army demanded all white captives be released before leaving the Kiowa alone. Thus, she's a lost, lonely, scared, angry little girl. Hanks is forced to be the one who is in charge of her safe return to an aunt and uncle in Castroville Texas, far to the South. They start out in a wagon with supplies and a single horse. Slowly, Johanna gets used to her new dress and boots, coffee, and learning English. Not liking each other at first, Kidd and Johanna bond well. But, there are perils on the journey such as dust storms and steep trails. The most horrible peril involves three men who want to "buy" Johanna to sell her into the sex trade (yes even back then!). Will they fight back against these dangers and make it to Castroville? This beautiful touching film has an abundance of assets. Hanks, of course, is always a fine performer but, here, even he is upstaged by Zengel. What a wonder this German child star is! Her eyes are big and expressive and she speaks Kiowa like she was born to it! In fact, her performance gives the film its ten rating as she is amazing. Also nice, however, is the sweeping cinematography, the wonderful creations of the towns and costumes, and the haunting musical score. The NEWS today is DON'T MISS THIS FILM!

Review title: Too Subtle & Understated For Its Own Good
Review_body: "News of the World" has all the elements that constitute a great film (Western in genre or otherwise): an interesting narrative/plot, beautiful cinematography, a generational acting talent, and a subtle social message behind it all. Unfortunately, every one of those aspects is played so subtly that the overall experience doesn't leave the viewer with much to chew over besides the base level of what is transpiring.For a very basic overview, "News of the World" sees Captain Kidd (Tom Hanks)--a Civil War veteran who now travels around reading newspapers to citizens--stumble upon a tragic ambush in which young Johanna (Helena Zengel) is left on her own. Johanna, taken by the Kiowa tribe at a young age, has no one but distant relatives standing between her and a life in orphanages (or worse). Somewhat reluctantly, Kidd agrees to take Johanna to those relatives, encountering a host of situations--both adventurous and enlightening--along the way.First and foremost, the biggest reason for the middling ranking is that I felt as if the Kidd character never really gave viewers enough to truly root for in terms of emotion. He's a good, decent man at the beginning of the film and a--good, decent man at the end (rendering the endgame fairly predictable by definition). It's not as if Hanks doesn't give a fine performance, because he does, but he's given so little range with which to work. I wanted director Paul Greengrass to let Hanks emote a bit more, but that wasn't in the cards for this picture."News of the World" also cultivates (at least initially) the interesting "reading the news" angle. This is clearly relevant in a post-Trump era. It portrays news as important and relevant to individual and community life. As with the acting, however, I wanted so much more of this thread. Besides a scene at the beginning and a scene at the end, it felt like the untapped potential here was almost criminal.Perhaps the best way to explain my ambivalence towards this film is in its closing scene. In it, Hanks gets to be, well, Hanks and indulges in a jubilant news-reading session full of humor and cheer. It was, truly, the first and only time I smiled--or emoted much at all--during the whole experience. By no means am I saying this movie should have been happy and cheery all around. But whether up or down, so to speak, I wanted the tone to really hit those highs and lows instead of taking such an even keel.Perhaps the best comp I can give for "News of the World" is 2014's "The Homesman", another movie that had all the necessary ingredients for success but couldn't pull them all together. As in that film, this one just remains too understated to ever elicit much viewer emotion.

Review title: A pleasant but unremarkable old-school Western.
Review_body: Renowned for his work on gritty thrillers such as The Bourne Ultimatum/Supremacy, United 93 and Green Zone, News of the World is without doubt the most easy going and dialed back Paul Greengrass film we've yet seen.An adaptation of Paulette Jiles novel, this Western set drama that reunites Greengrass with his Captain Philips star Tom Hanks (once more playing a captain, this time of the Civil War variety) sees the director put away the shaky cam/doco style of film-making that he made his name with and go about his business in a more typical and mild-mannered approach as we follow Hank's Captain Kidd in a new era of his life as he roams the wild west reading news and finds himself caring for orphaned girl Johanna after a chance encounter on the murderous plains of the American frontier.Selling to Netflix for a worldwide distribution after a brief cinematic run in the United States earlier this year, News is a prestigious looking film that carries a mid-tier level budget (plus some great work by renowned D.O.P Dariusz Wolski) and the presence of the always affable Hanks offers the film weight but despite the craftsmanship on display and notable turns from its lead actors, including a star making turn from child actress Helena Zengel, News isn't able to become a new classic of the genre as it struggles to become anything more than a pleasant diversion.Without expecting too much from the film and placing upon its shoulders unwarranted expectations there are feelings early on that News (a film that seems to share DNA with fellow western True Grit) will be that special type of old-school genre offering full of heart, soul and memorable moments and whilst there are sprinklings of wit, heart and soul throughout, the central friendship between Kidd and Johanna never excels and is never given time to properly flourish while the films various moments of despair and thrills are frequent but mostly unmemorable in their delivery.It's hard to put a finger on exactly what is missing in the film to make it click into gear to reach that next level but there's a distinct lack of movie magic here that would've made otherwise pleasing but forgettable set ups something more outstanding and there's a feeling that so much more could've been gained from various characters or instances that occur to Kidd and Johanna and while Hanks and Zengel do as much as they could've done with Greengrass's and Luke Davies script, considering the talent and potential here, News could've and perhaps should've been a new western classic.Final Say -A pleasing but forgettable old school Western that is missing a distinct if hard to describe charm and imagination, News of the World is solid stuff elevated by Hanks and Zengal but their respective characters and the world in which they live and breathe in had a lot more to give.3 1/2 tins of sugar out of 5

Review title: Celebrating 40 years of Tom Hanks with this 1870s western road movie
Review_body: "News Of the World" (2020 releae; 118 min.) brings the story of Captain Jefferson Kidd. As the movie opens, the Captain is somewhere in Texas where he is reading from local and national newspapers for a crowd that has paid 10 cents per person. The next day as the Captain is traveling top the next town, he stumbles upon a lynched black man, and a little white girl hiding in the bushes. From official papers, the Captain gathers this is Johanna, who was being trasported back to her family after having been kidnapped by Natives. The Captain tries, and fails, to drop Johanna off at the nearest army point, and in the end he is resigned to take Johanna to her family 400 miles away... At this point we are less than 15 minutes into the movie, but to tell you more of the plot would s;poil your viewing experience, you'll just have to see for yourself how it all plays out.Couple of comments: this is the latest from director Paul Greengrass (best known for various Bourne films). Here he reunites with Tom Hanks (folllowing 2013's "Captain Phillips") to bring what in essence is a western road movie set not long after the conlcusion of the Civil War, let's just call it the 1870s. This is the big screen adaptation of the book of the same name by Paulette Jiles. I haven't read the book and hence cannot comment on how close the movie sticks to the book. What I can say is that this is a very comfortable, if not predictable, western road movie. I mean, there really isn't a single surprise or plot twist that had me thinking "wow, I don't see that one coming!". That is not to say that this is a 'bad' movie. In fact, I enjoyed it quite a bit, none more so than the lead performance from Tom Hanks, who is in virtually every single frame of the movie. I am going to go on record already that Hanks will get a Best Actor Oscar nomination, and in fact he may even win it. It blows the mind that 2020 marks 40 years of Tom Hanks on the big screen (his 1980 debut? "He Knows You're Alone"). What better way than to get a star vehicle like "News of the World" provides."News of the World" premiered on Christmas Day in a limited theater run (the movie shifts to Netflix in mid-January). The New Year's Eve screening where I saw this at was attended okay (about 15 people, which is peanuts in 'normal' times, but is about the largest theater crowd I've seen since I started going back to the movies in early September for "Tenet"). If you love a decent if somewhat predictable western, or you are simply a fan of Tom Hanks, I'd readily suggest you check this out, be it in the theater, on VOD, or eventually on DVD/Blu-ray, and draw your own conclusion.

Review title: There is so much to like about this movie from beginning to end. I strongly recommend seeing this.
Review_body: News of the World (2020) is a movie the Mrs and I caught in theatres during the pandemic. The storyline focuses on a man who makes a living by collecting newspapers and going town to town in the west reading it to the locals who unfortunately cannot read or keep up with the ongoings of the world. One day he comes across a little girl who was caught by the native Americans and later deserted. He is left to take care of her and decides to take her to her closest kin. In his voyage we see how savage the world really is during this period...and how the white men are truly the savages and ill informed. This movie is directed by Paul Greengrass (United 93 and Bourne Ultimatum) and stars Tom Hanks (Forest Gump), Helena Zengel (System Crasher), Tom Astor (Mile 22) and Bill Camp (Joker and 12 Years a Slave). The storyline, cinematography, grit, landscape, backdrop and costumes were all out of this world in this movie. This picture does such a great job of depicting some of the challenges of the settlers, the uniqueness of how people lived and scrapped by, and the ignorance that has plagued this country since its inception. The acting, dialogue and resolve of each character is presented so well. There is so much to like about this movie from beginning to end. I strongly recommend seeing this and would score it a 9/10.

This film doesn't really have many supporting characters, it is just people coming in and then leaving before you get the chance to get interested or give an appraisal of their performance. This is of course not true for the main supporting character the young girl played by Helena Zengel and I read that this was her first ever English speaking film so maybe I should be lenient on her but I just can't be because I just found her character annoying. I'm pretty sure it's not her fault but the character was written poorly and the only reason I cared about the plot and things is because of the strength of Hanks performance. Hopefully Zengel keeps doing English speaking films as I think there is quality here and maybe she just needs a bit more experience.Story
The story was a mixed bag for me, Hanks personal story and development as the film progresses is well handled and Hanks does a great job with that and seeing these characters travelling through the west is pretty cool. But I also felt very little actually happened, it is like these mini stories that don't connect very well and it was just these two people going through the west with little direction. Also the ending is really predictable, no spoilers but it goes about as you would expect which is a bit disappointing.Script
The script is okay, kind of like the story Hanks delivers some great lines and his character is well written but the rest of the film isn't that great. I didn't fully buy into the relationship between the two of them and as I said before the film is split into smaller parts and it doesn't quite work and feels like a bit of a hodgepodge of stories.Style
The style of the film visually is fantastic, the West looks amazing and I think this film deserved to be seen in a cinema because it has a great look. But this film is very slow paced and it really holds the film back, if the story had been better then maybe it could have worked but I was just waiting for it to get going.Overall
Overall, I had high expectations with Tom Hanks & Director Paul Greengrass but this film let me down. It is just a very average western with a good lead performance and nothing else that stands out. If you like westerns and Hanks then maybe give it a go but it won't be one I ever rush to see again.

News of the World is an emotional western drama set only just after the conclusion of the devastating Civil War. Veteran Captain Kidd has lost his wife to a disease while being at the front line. He tries to escape his grim past by traveling through the country and reading newspapers to citizens in order to inspire change and hope. One day, he comes across a carriage that has been knocked over. The driver has been brutally murdered and the only survivor is a young girl who doesn't speak English. Captain Kidd discovers that her name is Johanna and that she got kidnapped by the Kiowa as a child when they murdered her entire family. She has spent most of her childhood with the Kiowa and her identity is much closer to Native American culture than to her German origins. Captain Kidd plans on bringing her to her aunt, uncle and cousins but the two protagonists have to travel through the entire state of Texas for about six weeks to get there. On their challenging journey, they come across human traffickers and radical militia and must face carriage accidents and sandstorms.This wonderful western convinces on numerous levels. First of all, the characters are truly intriguing with the grieving, kind-hearted and well-mannered captain and the wild, lost and intelligent child. The acting performances by Tom Hanks and Helena Zengel are absolutely outstanding and would certainly deserve Academy Awards nominations. The different segments of the movie are truly intriguing as well as the protagonists come across hateful and helpful characters and face beautiful and dangerous natural phenomenons. The locations have been chosen with care and bring the war beauty of the Wild West to life in an authentic way. The camera work is calm and precise, the sound effects are immersive and intense and the soundtrack underlines the movie's atmosphere perfectly.Even though the movie might have a few minor lengths here and there, News of the World is one of the greatest contemporary westerns in recent memory. The excellent acting performances, profound characters and diversified plot shouldn't only please genre fans but anyone craving for a heartfelt drama with some tense action scenes. This movie hasn't received the attention it deserves due to the pandemic, so make sure to watch it once cinemas in your region are reopening. While Tom Hanks confirms his status as one of the greatest actors of all time, News of the World is also the breakthrough performance for young German actress Helena Zengel who will hopefully be casted for further Hollywood movies instead of wasting her precious talent on sleep-inducing German televison movies.

Tom Hanks reunites w/his Captain Phillips director, Paul Greengrass (Flight 93/Jason Bourne), in this Western which deals w/a news reader trying to bring a white child (who's family was killed & raised by Indians) back to the only living kin she has after he discovers her initial transport was killed as well. A former Civil War soldier who fought for the South at the expense of his wife (who died of cholera waiting four years for him to come home) now plies his trade as a newspaper reader (presented as a show of sorts to the masses who probably at that time didn't know how to read or were looking for any kind of entertainment) who still commands a modicum of respect & stature even at this stage in his life so when he comes upon the blonde waif, played by Helena Zengel (who calls him Captain, I guess an unintentional refrain from Captain Phillips), he's incapable of not doing the right thing by escorting the girl to a nearby town who tells him the nearest Indian agent is miles away which he reluctantly does & then again when he hits a wall there, he decides to bring the girl all the way to her nearest relations (an aunt) defending against a trio of bandits hoping to steal the girl & a hostile town where mob rule has taken root & the defacto leader wants to use Hanks to his whims (which backfires by the by!). If you've seen enough Westerns (here's my 'hold my beer' moment!), this is isn't exactly new ground but since movie Westerns have gone the way of the dodo, any time a modern filmmaker takes a stab at an oater, it should be welcomed & appreciated (w/selections like Netflix's Godless or even something like Cowboys Vs. Aliens, you won't be disappointed) which Greengrass does exceedingly well here. Also starring Ray McKinnon & Mare Winningham as a couple Hanks leaves Zengel with at the outset, Elizabeth Marvel as another person Hanks has some history with & the current character actor du jour, Bill Camp (last seen in the Netflix hit Queen's Gambit as the janitor who teaches the prodigy about chess) seen here as a hometown friend of Hanks.

IN BRIEF: Fine direction and an understated performance by Mr. Hanks elevates this familiar western tale and its conventional storytelling.JIM'S REVIEW: (RECOMMENDED) Moviegoing has always been an escape from the news of our world and News of the World, a highly entertaining western tale by Paul Greengrass, is a fine respite that makes its presence known. The film definitely has a "been there, done that" vibe as it follows a predictable road trip through glorious American panoramas in very uncertain times. The story takes place in 1870, but the parallels from then and now are strikingly similar with today's contemporary issues of racial hatred, a dreaded disease debilitating the country, the still pressing issue of real vs. fake news, and a polarized nation unable to come together. Subtle, surprisingly yes, but revisionist, absolutely also. To its credit, the film avoids preachy sermonizing as it concentrates on its interesting characters and their misfortunes.Set in the post Civil War Texas badlands, former Confederate officer Captain Jefferson Kyle Kidd (Tom Hanks) travels the country sharing news stories at ten cents a read. His profitable form of stage entertainment, a traveling one-man show-and-tell, allows him to encounter a cross-section of America strife. One day between engagements, he discovers an orphaned white girl named Joanna (Helena Zengel) dressed in Native American garb and only speaking the Kiowa language. He decides to take her back to the safety of her family and inherits the role of her temporary guardian. Their trek together and their eventual bonding is the main scenario in this mediative tale of kinship.The screenplay by Lucas Davies and the director is quite formulaic as the lonesome twosome run into many obstacles along the way (outlaws, profiteers, natural disasters), but the dialog is literate and insightful, even if the plot literally moves from one peril to the next. But the film is is so beautifully made and a worthy throwback to its Western genre. Mr. Greengrass tells his tale with vigor and style by allowing his characters and their relationships to build gradually. The production values are top-notch with Dariusz Wolski's sweeping photography and James Newton Howard's lyrical music score contributing to the film's sense of grandeur. At the midway point, there is the film's major set piece, a thrilling shoot-out in the Texan foothills, extremely well edited by William Goldenburg. This memorable sequence is wonderfully staged and brimming with tension, though nothing else in the movie attains that accomplished level of excitement.One of the foremost reasons for the film's success is the central casting of Mr. Hanks as our protagonist. The actor is thoroughly convincing and creates an indelible character of a descent man dealing with his own internal hardships and still trying to move forward. His nuanced portrayal is so skillfully performed that it is easy to overlook its overall impact. As his charge, Ms Zengel gives a totally natural performance. She may not be a young Natalie Wood circa The Searchers in her almost identical role, but Ms. Zengel is far more compelling and does not pander for moviegoers' sympathies. Solid support in minor roles comes from stalwart actors that include Mare Winningham, Elizabeth Marvel, Bill Camp, and Ray McKinnon.News of the World is a solid Western trope that may be too conventional in its storytelling, but it is nevertheless a rousing good time with Mr.Hanks and company. Saddle up, partner! (GRADE: B)

Review title: News Of A Classic Western Feel, but not Quite Finishing the Deal
Review_body:
LIKES:Beautifully Shot
The Western Frontier unfolds
Realism (mostly) that fits the Frontier
Some Character Growth
Action Scene that again Feels Very fitting
The Acting With ScoreDISLIKES:
Pacing Gradually Gets Worse As Story Progresses
Some of the Off The Way moments seem Shallow and Wedged in
A Last Minute Impasse Held Little Point
The Impromptu Answers at the last minute that extended the film without need
Depressing At Many Times
Review:There is one thing that continues to show improvement and that is how the camera work can capture a lot of the beautiful of the world. News of The World is a stylish, gorgeous display of the Western frontier and instilling with it the wild west nature of this genre. Through the use of various filters and natural setting to really craft the different levels of danger the 1800s wilderness provided. Costumes and makeup only further helped bring out the gritty nature of those days, and establish the danger of the outlaws that inhabited them. Bringing you into the world, the western frontier really unfolds, and brings you back into what made these types of movies shine in the past. The realism really helps with this, ditching aliens, stunts, and flashy scenes to instead take on a more down to earth movie. As Captain Kidd (Hanks) and Johanna (Zengel) continue to traverse the wilderness, one really feels the emotions of the scenes, the desperation of each step and trying to adapt to the situations at hands. Though not as exciting as some of my favorite Western movies, Greengrass and company have come up with clever ways to face the odds (mostly) and use some well-time monologues, strategy, and even kindness to assist the bravery and find a solution. One of these moments is a very good action scene that might not be flashy or filled with stunts, but still is suspenseful in the dark nature of the fight. The real life fight offers strategy given the odds, and has just enough draw out and planning to make you think twice about what the outcome will be. For me, it's brilliant because not only does it sort of add diversity to the film, but it also allows for some unorthodox character growth that movies struggle with these days. Each of these chapters on the adventure push our characters to face different demons, gradually changing them and trying to practice the lessons that each are trying to teach each other. All of this comes from great acting by the two leads, a sound chemistry between experience and new age that perfectly captures the dynamic they wanted. Hanks has another movie to add to his repertoire of awesome acting ability. His character is straightforward, and yet complex and Hanks hits all the marks as the scene requires, while seldom overcommitting to the part. As for young Zengel, for a role that primarily consisted of grunting, speaking different languages, and nonverbal acting, she accomplished this very well. Many roles like this are often more annoying than well done, but the direction of this film avoided that territory for the most part and knows just how much it takes to deliver the message without tearing my ears off in the process.
All of this good though does start to wane in some departments though, especially near the end where things seem to drop into a rushed mess. First of all, while not the fastest movie to begin with, the last thirty or so minutes really feels dragged out and a mess. Things that were swiftly moving suddenly rush into a few scenes that seem to hit a wall and then become ridiculous, not as exciting, shallow finishes that seem to drag on and on. A shame given the quality, and though it does complete the circle of events, it really felt the most off for me given the way the rest of the film presented. Many of those moments seemed shoe horned in, a visit to one location, a sudden storm that would reveal something elusive, and even the final destination were all so last minute to me that it lacked the full punch I think they were going for. One impasse in particular violated my cardinal rules and given what happens about eight minutes later, was completely unnecessary given the consequences that were seen (did not like this scene at all). And ironically, the last minute answers, and filling those holes were both needed, but not needed given how it extended the film to unnecessary lengths. About twenty minutes of the movie could have either been cut or condensed to give me the same information and still not bore me to the point of fighting sleep. Though this film has much more depressing elements than others, it's this end point especially that sucks the life from you and makes you question many things. Yes, for those that are fighting the 2020 blahs, this movie may not be for you given how tough grit it is, so exercise that caution before departing on the trail.The VERDICT:The high marks from rotten tomatoes and film credits are right in their remarks of how visually amazing this film is and how it's a breath of fresh air in regards to the movie telling. News of the World trades flair for being there and drops you back into the Wild West Frontier that captured so many young minds along time ago. Realistic travels, a world that is dangerous and engrossing, with very fitting moments are just some of the highlights to this film. Though this reviewer feels it's the acting and most of the character development that deserves praise as the strongest aspect of the movies. Despite all the good though, the movie's main weaknesses for me are the depressing nature of the film and the end where things seem to be sort of crammed together and yet extend the film. Taking all of that in, the results of the movie for me are;Action/Adventure/Drama: 7.0
Movie Overall: 6.0

Review title: A heartfelt account of an old newsreader and a life-changing mission.
Review_body: I haven't seen a lot of Westerns but needed to revisit the genre, and News of the World was a good way to experience that and then some. A simple, slow-burning but engaging travelogue-style action drama, this Western boasts some fine performances coming from Tom Hanks and Helena Zengel. Their well-developed bonding is a treat to watch, and how their conversations surpass the evident language barrier is a great metaphor.Director Paul Greengrass, better known for the fast-paced Bourne films, does a splendid job directing a slow, simple, grounded film about an old newsreader and a new mission that changes his life. The concept sure doesn't sound new but the film totally takes advantage of it and that is evident from the ample investment in characters. Also, Greengrass holds attention with the action sequences devoid of his usual shaky camera technique, and keeps you on the edge of your seat. The central shootout scene, for example, is not merely well choreographed or filmed, but also written intelligently a served with a suspenseful tone for an otherwise dramatic film.The film's plot centers around a journey, and hence it feels like a collection of several episodes, which is suitable given the theme. The score by James Newton Howard is captivating, and a reason enough to stay during the credits. The cinematography is splendid, capturing the picturesque locales with brilliance. Editing is also good, as the pacing doesn't remain the same throughout and changes as per the scenes, which becomes evident especially during the action sequences.All in all, this is a heartfelt Western, and those new to the genre can be convinced to explore it more after watching this film. It has got all the right elements to cater to majority of viewers, ranging from strong performances to captivating drama to thrilling action scenes to adventurous locales. Nothing feels overdone or out of place. A good watch for cinema lovers who would love to see a film come to life and involve them as they watch the emotional adventure unfold.
