Review title: Paul Greengrass teams up with Tom Hanks once again with a great western film, it met my expectations and I hope it meets yours
Review_body:
News of the World is co-written and directed by Paul Greengrass, and based on the 2016 novel of the same name by Paulette Jiles. Since it got announced that Tom Hanks was gonna star in this film that's how long I've looked forward to it. Paul Greengrass have showed multiple of times with films like the Bourne trilogy and Captain Phillips that he's a great filmmaker, seeing him tackle the western genre made me excited and he didn't disappoint.
The story is set in 1870 and follows a Civil War veteran who must return a young girl who was taken in by Native Americans as an infant to her last remaining family.Tom Hanks plays Captain Jefferson Kyle Kidd and Helena Zengel plays Johanna Leonberger/Cicada. Their performances are one of the film's highlights, they are very good and realistic. Tom Hanks nails the accent and overall feeling of a person who lived in 1870 whilst Helena Zengel brings a terrific performance and had to learn Kiowa which deserves praise.
The supporting cast has for example RayMcKinnon and Elizabeth Marvel, there's of course more actors in the cast but it's mostly just smaller roles as the film is about Captain Jefferson Kidd and Johanna Leonberger, and their journey, their travels.The director, Paul Greengrass has the visual storytelling on point, using the show don't tell to show off backstory for our protagonists. Overall superb direction.
The cinematography is breathtaking, such a nicely shot movie. There's not much more to say other than it deserves a nomination for best cinematography.
The musical score was done by James Newton Howard, it's one of his best of those I have heard. The soundtrack has so many instruments authentic to the era, both from Native American and regular, mixing them both for a perfect and powerful score that's full with suspense.
The sound design is incredible, every single sound in the movie feels so real and it makes it so easy to get immersed.Now this film is far from an action movie but there is gunfights in it, some of the realistic ones I have seen, they nailed the sound and effects. But most importantly, the realistic and brutal ways of gunfights.
The whole film is well made, some of the finest piece of cinema I have seen. The whole production design is top notch, you'll see some stunning set pieces and a western worth remembering.News of the World was named one of the ten best films of 2020 by the National Board of Review, and I agree fully with them. If you're a fan of westerns or just interested in a period film then you'll lost likely enjoy this one, I strongly believe that there's something for everyone in this film. They managed to create a fantastic film filled with incredible acting and memorable set pieces. But I do understand that it isn't for everyone because of the slow pace but I felt it fitted the tone of the film perfectly and how they travel. It gave the writers and director time for character development and for us viewers to really get to know the characters.

Pound for pound, Tom Hanks is the best actor of this generation. From his big screen debut in SPLASH to his Oscar Nominated turn in BIG to his back-to-back Oscar wins for PHILADELPHIA and FORREST GUMP to more recent works like SULLY and THE POST, Hanks' "everyman goodness" quality shines through the screen and makes him a screen presence that cannot be ignored.And in his latest effort, the Paul Greengrass Directed NEWS OF THE WORLD, Hanks uses every molecule of his screen presence to keep the audience's attention in a slow-paced, moody character study.Based on the novel by Paulette Jiles, NEWS OF THE WORLD takes place in a post-Civil War Texas where a former Confederate Captain makes a living by going from town to town and reading the news to them. A chance encounter with a twice orphaned young girl alters the lives of both of them.Writer/Director Paul Greengrass is most known for quick-cut action films like the BOURNE series or the criminally underrated GREEN ROOM, so he would seem - at first glance - as an unusual choice to adapt and direct this character study, but look further at Greengrass' resume and you will find - in films such as UNITED 93 and CAPTAIN PHILLIPS - an ability to tell a story that is driven more by character than by action.And this combination of Director and Actor works well for NEWS OF THE WORLD is a languidly paced piece that has a somber mood and look but Greengrass avoids the temptation of lingering on scenes or pictures too long (and there are some wonderful images captured by Greengrass and Cinemotgrapher Darius Wolski) to tell a story of a man who needs to rediscover and remake himself.And Hanks is more than equal to the task of bringing the pragmatic, introspective Captain Jefferson Kyle Kidd character to life in a way that makes him intriguing and not boring. Hanks ability to show inherent decency in a look or a gesture is the stuff of legends and when he speaks, you listen. Which is good for Hanks is in every scene in this film and his performance needs to strongly capture the audience for this film to work - and he is more than equal to this task - so strong is Hanks in this role that I would not be surprised if there is another Oscar nomination in Tom's near future.Newcomer Helena Zegal is "just fine" in the other main role in this film - the young girl that Captain Kidd encounters, Johnna. This young girl is silent and shut down for most of the film and Zegal performs "shut down and silent" well. Also along for brief cameo roles of characters that Captain Kidd encounters on his journey is a bevy of wonderfully cast character actors that include Mare Winnigham, Ray McKinnon, Bill Camp and the always interesting to watch Elizabeth Marvel.As is often the case in these sorts of films, the music/soundtrack becomes a vital part of the story that unfolds and 8 time Oscar nominated composer James Newton Howard (THE PRINCE OF TIDES) is more than up to the task. The music is another character in this film and helps set the mood along the journey.But make no mistake, this is Hanks' film - and he is VERY good in this. Like MIDNIGHT SKY (reviewed last month), this movie will not be for everyone - and many, many folks are going to tell me that they checked this movie out on my recommendation and were bored by it. But...if you click into the mood, motion and energy of what Greengrass is showing, you will be rewarded with an emotionally rich and complex character study.Letter Grade: A-8 stars (out of 10) - and you can take that to the Bank (ofMarquis)

Review title: A western film that shows the drama side rather than the gun battles galore
Review_body: The Western genre is retrod with great effect in this film from 2020 that has a story that veers away from the traditional western film screenplay clichés of cowboys and Indians and delivers an emotive story from the era.In a nutshell we have a Civil War veteran played by Tom Hanks, Captain Jefferson Kidd who goes from town to town reading newspapers/the news to willing audiences. It is a stark reminder that 24 hour rolling news channels and social media didn't exist in the period that the film is set, 1870. How old are the newspapers he reads from. I have no idea!After one such reading and travelling to the next location Kidd stumbles on an overturned wagon in the road and a dead black soldier and young white girl dressed in native Indian clothing. Still alive. A girl who speaks no English but Kiowa. A language of the Comanche tribes.The girl is played by Helena Zengel, a German actress. Her performance in the film is a highlight.Reluctantly Kidd looks after the girl until she can be returned to her surviving family. However when he gets to the next town, the Union officials tell him that the representative of the Bureau of Indian Affairs who will sort out her paperwork is away for three months! He either looks after the girl or abandons her basically.The film reminded me of films such as True Grit (1969 and 2010 remake) with the older battle weary character and a younger girl character.The film features sweeping cinematography that would look fantastic on a large cinema screen but still is great on a television screen and defies its streaming platform release in international territories. The landscapes would do John Ford proud!As Kidd transports the girl across a dangerous Texas environment to the girl's surviving family he encounters criminals who wish to purchase the girl. Hanks character Kidd at one point attempts to reason like the characters in one of his other film collaborations with director Paul Greengrass, Captain Phillips (2013).In another scene we see his ex-army skills being used to full effect in a shoot out complete with assistance from the girl who by now we learn has an Indian name of Cicada.Director Greengrass rightfully has earned plaudits for his direction of the film. In another scene we see Kidd incite civil unrest against a radical band of militia.After the girl is delivered to her aunt and uncle and exploration of Kidd's own history in which his wife died. Kidd returns to the village to see Johanna cruelly tied to a pole like a dog and takes her away.Hanks is great in these films although I have never seen him in a western as such.

Review title: Frequently treads familiar territory in terms of storytelling but makes up for it with its solid acting and directing
Review_body: "News of the World" is a Western film based on the novel of the same name by Paulette Jiles. Directed by Paul Greengrass (The Bourne Supremacy, United 93, Captain Phillips) and starring Tom Hanks in the lead role, it frequently treads familiar territory in terms of storytelling but makes up for it with its solid acting and directing.In 1870, Civil War veteran Captain Jefferson Kidd (Tom Hanks) makes a living by travelling throughout various towns in Texas reading the newspapers to local residents at ten cents a head. After one particular evening of keeping a town informed, Kidd discovers an overturned wagon and a young blonde-haired, fair-skinned girl named Johanna (Helena Zengel) seemingly abandoned wearing Native American attire. Upon reporting Johanna to the local authorities, Kidd is told that it will be three months before someone will be able to return her to her surviving family located several miles south and despite his reluctance and her lack of cooperation, decides to take her there himself.I've been a fan of Westerns for as long as I can remember, with "The Good, The Bad and the Ugly" being one of my all time favourite movies and the "Red Dead Redemption" games ranking among the best I've ever played. I suppose it's just the simplicity of these stories mixed with gunslinging action that attracts me to this genre so much. A film like "News of the World" certainly isn't groundbreaking in any of these regards, but it successfully gets the job done in the most satisfying way possible. On the surface, the film is littered with predictable Western tropes like shootouts with bandits, the inhospitable hot climate, and the aftermath of the American Civil War still fresh in the minds of many people. Yet, in spite of all of this, the film managed to rise above most of it thanks to a talented lead actor taking the reins and an equally talented director guiding us through the whole experience. If it were any other pairing, a film like this may not have worked at all, likely sinking without a trace among others of this genre, but instead we have an entertaining Western that engages the audience from start to finish in the face of obvious cliches.Under Paul Greengrass's direction, the film moves along at a surprisingly slower pace than one would expect of a Western like this. Normally that would be frustrating but I felt that it allowed the audience to properly take in and appreciate the atmosphere of the old American West in all its arid glory. The people encountered and the locations camped at became more involving as a result and weren't simply glanced over in favour of moving the story along. Additionally, his choices in cinematography showcase how vast and dangerous the land our two characters must traverse to reach where they are going. Since the film is set in Texas, one of the largest American states by sheer size, it is a firm reminder of how much ground must be covered if the two of them wish to arrive in one piece. All of this made me think of the old saying that it is the journey itself and not the destination that is most important in any adventure and I believe that can definitely be applied here.As to be expected, Tom Hanks does a great job in the lead role, bringing the usual affable everyman qualities we are accustomed to seeing in virtually all of his performances. Interestingly, this is the first Western character Hanks has played in his career (unless you count Woody from the Toy Story films) and yet he approaches the role so naturally that it may as well be one of many. However, it is young newcomer Helena Zengel who stands out the most as Johanna. I enjoyed her interactions with Hanks's character, even though she barely understands any English, and watching them grow closer as an almost father/daughter pairing felt rewarding as the film progressed. This is also Zengel's first English language film and hopefully it will open the door for her to other similar projects in the near future.In conclusion, while this film doesn't really do anything new, it still felt fresh as ever mainly due to its main star and director. Francis Ford Coppola once said that there aren't any new stories to tell anymore and that our best bet would be to tell one in our own unique way and this film does indeed feel told in a way any Western fan can enjoy and forgive most of its shortcomings. Other films out there could definitely benefit from that approach, though one can only hope their filmmakers will actually follow suit.I rate it 8/10

The stage curtains open ..."News Of The World", though nothing new or remarkable, is fresh in its approach and delivery. On the road one day, he chances upon a young girl named Johanna, who is alone in the world. He befriends her and takes it upon himself, despite the dangers it brings to him and her, to conduct her safely to her nearest living relative where the law states she belongs. As the two unlikely's travel together, they form a bond ... one that will be put to test time and again leading to the film's final dilemma and conclusion.As mentioned before, it is a familiar story, yet this effort was delivered with a lot of heart. Review title: Striking visuals with an ordinary and predictable story
Review_body: It's nice to see Paul Greengrass reunite with Tom Hanks again after Captain Phillips but this film isn't as good or as memorable as their first collaboration.News of the World follows Civil War veteran Captain Jefferson Kyle Kidd who travels town to town reading the news to its residents. Along the way he finds a young girl and agrees to take her to her aunt and uncle.This is a story that we've seen being played out countless times in the past. It is very predictable and goes down paths that are very familiar. What I really did like about the film was its presentation. This film is a western and Paul Greengrass did a terrific job conveying that to us. The production design, costumes and cinematography make this one of Greengrass's most visually striking films. The lighting too was utilised well which is one of my favourite parts of westerns. The score was also beautiful and brought a lot of atmosphere to the film's world. In terms of its technical aspects, News of the World does a spectacular job creating the western world and breathing life into it. There is one particular shootout scene which has its tense moments but this is one of Greengrass's more sombre and slower films so the lack of action may leave some people restless.The heart and soul of the film really come from the two lead performances. Tom Hanks is excellent as usual. The energy and charisma he brings to the character when he's reading the news makes him so likeable and even the subtleties he brings to his performance paves the way for the film's more emotional moments that make you truly care about him. Helena Zengel does deliver a surprisingly great performance. At first I wasn't so sure but later on she improved and made me feel more attached to her. I'm hoping to see her in more films in the future.All in all, News of the World is a decent western. Apart from its beautiful visuals and the performances, there isn't much else that makes this film stand out. It's another ordinary tale told well but I don't see myself remembering it or wanting to watch it again.

IN A NUTSHELL:
There were soooo many movies that came out around Christmas that I just recently found time to watch the newest Tom Hanks film. In case you missed it too, here's the scoop! Before TV news anchors, traveling newsreaders would relay the day's headlines across the country "for anyone with 10 cents and the time to hear it." Family
Home

SecretsTHINGS I LIKED:

Director Paul Greengrass and Tom Hanks worked together in the powerful movie Captain Phillips.

She was born and raised in Berlin and began her career at the ripe old age of five in a music video. movies She has that unique spark of a true star and we're sure to see a lot more of her after this performance. After one look at her audition, director Greengrass said it was the easiest decision he made in the film. It's the first time he has made a movie with a child actor at the heart of it. She plays an orphaned girl who was raised by the Kiowa Indians. When she was interviewed, she said she had never heard of Tom Hanks before. Believable special effects and scenarios.
The silence is even more powerful than the spoken words.
The film features dangers both by humans and nature.

Not much humor to balance out the drama.

Review title: A Light and Entertaining Road Western
Review_body: News of the World follows wild west Newsman Captain Kidd as he travels from town to town, delivering the news to remote townsfolk across southern Texas. After one particular reading, he stumbles across a ransacked wagon carrying a young orphaned girl, and finds himself put in charge of getting her to her aunt and uncle. This is fundamentally a road movie, as we follow Kidd and Johanna on their journey from town to town, meeting an eclectic array of locals, and finding themselves in all kinds of trouble.This is a fairly light movie though. There's nothing here to particularly challenge the viewer. There's no big twist, no deep subtext to decipher, nothing particularly gritty worth sticking your teeth into. It has its emotional moments, but they're reigned in to keep focus on the relationship between Kidd and Johanna, and there's moments of tension and suspense, but ultimately nothing particularly bad ends up happening to either character (or at least nothing too bad after the movie starts). Johanna's upbringing is one full of tragedy, losing her blood family in a brutal attack on their homestead, which she later visits to see looted and full of blood smeared over the walls. She was then taken in by Kiowa natives, learned their language and drenched in their culture, but she was left as the only survivor of her tribe after an attack by the local colonialists. Kidd on the other hand hasn't seen his wife in over five years, since he left for the war and then started travelling to read the news. He left his life behind and refuses to return for fear of what he might find there, but just like Johanna goes back to her family's homestead, Kidd too goes back to San Antonio to put his demons to rest.The closest this movie gets to an underlying theme and message is that of the nature of stories, and the news in particular. Kidd makes it his life's work to ensure the hard working men and women of America know what's going on in the world around them, even if doesn't directly affect them. He calms down a rowdy rabble upon hearing of president Ulysses S. Grant's intentions to grant black people more rights and freedoms, but also incites a rebellion in a closed-off town ruled by an outlaw dictator by telling them the story of a group of miners who survived a deadly fire against all odds. News of the World gives us a hero in a Western who changes the world with his words and his stories rather than with gunsAlthough to be sure he certainly meets troubles that can't be won with words alone, resulting in the movie's few but suspenseful action sequences. A group of ex-soldiers looking to kidnap Johanna besiege Kidd on a hilltop, forcing him to think outside the box to fend them off, while his incited revolt lands him in big trouble with the outlaw leader. While these action setpieces are draped in suspense and tension, the ultimate outcome is never too shocking or plot-changing. Kidd and Johanna manage to get out of both scuffles largely unfazed, which could lead to some complaints of predictability or plot armour, but hey, it's a light and entertaining movie. They don't all need to be narratively challenging.Possibly my favourite aspect of this movie though was the representation of Native Americans. While they're portrayed with respect throughout, Greengrass goes further by depicting them as almost otherworldly, bathed in dust or fog, always traveling from one place to another. They're neither aggressive nor naively innocent, but just people doing their best to survive, at one with nature and the spirits around them. The film also avoids the temptation to return Johanna to a Native American tribe, acknowledging that she's just as much a Native as she is a Colonialist. She's a girl without a family and without a home, and she no longer fits in with either side. But it certainly flirts with who she'll eventually settle with. As a light and unchallenging movie the answer is ultimately obvious, but that doesn't stop it from daggling the possibilities in front of both us and Captain Kidd.The acting from Tom Hanks and Helena Zengel is fantastic, offering up so much in their performances without words. Every glance and shift in body language says a thousand words between them, overcoming the multiple layers of language and culture barriers between them. As much as this movie is about the power of truth and stories, it's also about the relationship between these two characters, and a large portion of the film's dramatic entertainment comes from seeing that adoration between them flourish.Lastly the film looks gorgeous. It has some shaky moments of CGI from time-to-time, but nothing too distracting. However the cinematography offers some breathtaking shots of the local scenery, bathed in ethereal lighting. Particular highlights include dusklit campfires, silhouettes in the dust storm, and Johanna calling out to a travelling tribe of Natives across a raging river in the dead of night. But what the film does really well is creates an immersive atmosphere of 1870s Texas. You're transported back to the western frontier and told to just live in it and its people. It gave me the same feeling playing Red Dead Redemption gave me, just lifted from my 2021 lifestyle and planted fully in another time entirely. It wasn't too gritty and miserable, but it also wasn't too afraid of the darker elements of that life to gloss over them entirely. The danger on the road, or out in uncharted territory, the relative safety of the larger towns, the pervasive lawlessness, but full of people just living their lives.News of the World is not a remarkable movie by any means. It's movie that will be largely forgotten about as time goes on. It's a safe, light movie made for pure, sentimental entertainment. There's nothing here to challenge the viewer, nor does it attempt anything particularly new. It's pure escapism, watching Tom Hanks be his usual friendly, selfless character delivering news, and bonding with an orphaned girl along the way. It's just a solid good time free of baggage. I give it an enjoyable 7/10.

"I'm here tonight to bring the news from across the great world of ours."A Civil War veteran agrees to deliver a girl, taken by the Kiowa people years ago, to her aunt and uncle, against her will. They travel hundreds of miles and face grave dangers as they search for a place that either can call home. Paul Greengrass is an outstanding director and that's something everyone can agree on. His take on a western felt like a promising entry after the success of Captain Phillips. Though News of the World doesn't deliver as much as we wanted it to, it's still a good movie. Greengrass collaborated with Luke Davies (writer of Lion and Beautiful Boy) to adapt the novel. There isn't much that we haven't seen before. Most of the time I could tell what was to come. Even with some of the dialogue I could tell where it would go. I think that's where most of my issues come from. I wanted something more but I got a basic western. Most everyone likes the movie but the reviews are extremely high for what it is.Tom Hanks gives another good performance. He and Greengrass definitely have a shared connection. But the real star is Helena Zengel. I felt most connected with her character even with the language barrier and how little information we have on her. The decision to have subtitles with her kind of bugged me. Without the subtitles I feel a better emotion could've been created. For example, there's a scene with her crying out. It's sad what's happening but I think it would've been greater if we didn't know what those exact words were. We understand what she's saying but knowing more made the impact less.Greengrass definitely had an eye for what he wanted this to look like. The production design feels like a classic western as we from town to town. The same goes for the costumes. The cinematography looks pretty good. I had some issues with a few scenes having the blue filter to make it look darker and random zoom-in/zoom-outs that felt out of place. The score gets you in the mood for what's to come. It really just does what you'd expect it to. I like News of the World but it felt like a letdown in the end. Like I said, everything is too predictable and cliche for any surprises with the story or characters and the stakes never seemed high. Maybe this is the type of movie you're looking for. Some people are coming out having a good time. I just needed more.

I really enjoyed watching News of the World. He just has so much gravitas, charm, and you instantly feel a connection to any character he is playing. Surprisingly he is upstaged by the incredibly talented Helena Zengel who steals the show. Her performance, considering it was one of little dialogue, was outstanding and was so captivating. The relationship between her and Hanks felt so real. You could feel the growing connection and were rooting for them from start to finish.I would have scored this film higher but I thought the plot was a bit of let down. I enjoyed the underlying premise, but felt that it could have done a lot more. There was lots of great stuff exploring the character of Captain Kidd and developing the relationship between the two, but I feel like the film could have been longer and spent a bit more time diving into this. As a result we would have got a much more satisfying emotional payout come the end of the film.On the whole though this is a solid watch as you'd expect from a Hanks film. It has a great western feel with an epic scale, while also managing to develop a very watchable and engaging partnership with our two protagonists.

But Hanks isn't the only one to take a turn because behind the camera Greengrass has stepped out of his comfort zone with this, he doesn't usually give us a slow yet an incredibly absorbing drama, in fact quite the opposite he usually gives us tense thrillers, while this may be a step out for him. It's also a step in for him as he seems very much at home, thus making News of the World a success. Granted it does suffer from narrative issues down the road but you can always rely on Hanks pulling out a trick up his sleeve yet again he's an absolute joy to watch and when the action slams into place both Hanks and Greengrass crank up the mayhem. Overall rating 78/100News of the world is about a civil war veteran called Kyle Kidd (Tom Hanks) who agrees to a deliver a girl called Johanna (Helena Zengel) taken by the kiowa people many years before, to her aunt and uncle,against her will. They travel hundreds of miles and face grave dangers as they both search for a place that either can call home. At first when I watched News of the world especially in the first half my review was going to be negative, but the luckily the movie just got better and better, further cementing Tom Hanks as an acting legend, so let's get started.My first few positives would be the amazing cinematography, the performances and likeable main character, as well as a good set up for character development. The movie looked absolutely beautiful, wherever News of the world was shot it was stunning, the creative team took complete advantage of the beautiful set locations for effective action sequences. The performances in this movie were also absolutely fantastic. Tom Hanks further proves that he is still an absolutely fantastic actor and a true legend of Hollywood, he was charming had heaps of charisma and showed a lot of emotional range to his character that was conveyed authentically. But what a debut performance from Helena Zengel, her performance was powerful, charming and moving, it really shows when you can make a character who doesn't know English so compelling and interesting to watch so she should get a lot of work from this and fact that she is twelve years old is astounding to me. I also thought the actual character of Kyle Kidd was very likeable, he was charming, kind and a great father figure to Johanna as their relationship blossomed, he was also a very peaceful man who promoted equality and change which I thought was powerfully done. I also thought the set up for character development was great, having both characters needing to find themselves and where they truly belonged was an excellent theme and was set up very well in the first half.However, my first few negatives that were mostly in the first half of the movie would be the dull and rushed opening with a lack of establishing the story world, the predictable conflict and the lack of clear or effective conflict. The movie was extremely dull and it thrust you into a scene with the main character and it just felt like the movie expected you to know the story world and the significance of the main characters actions, the first half in general was fairly dull and the main plot point was just lazily set up for me. I also thought that the conflict that they attempted within the first half with Johanna and with other characters felt very predictable and lazy, and it just lacked believability. One of my biggest issues with the first half was the lack of clear or effective conflict, there was attempts to bring in conflict but I never believed that they were an actual threat to the characters, so this severely impacted the pacing for me and it was poorly structured. My final negative for the first half was the randomly introduced characters that lacked any form or relevance or impact to the movie. There was just tacked on characters that were in the movie for five minutes to a brief scene with the main characters then they weren't really in the movie anymore, if the movie wanted more characters which I think it should have they should have had more screen time and depth to them.Now lets move on to some more positives would be the impactful themes linked to racism, the character depth and chemistry between the actors, as well as effective building of tension. The movie tackled its deep themes on the racism towards Indians in the 19th century very well the movie balanced its conflict of the different views of the time very well and built towards spreading a message of peace which I loved and it was very moving and powerful to me. I also thought that the character depth in the movie was excellent, not only was their great depth to its themes on racism but the main character had tremendous depth to him that really was very emotional, him losing his wife and never being able to have kids and him feeling guilty and responsible for what happened added tremendous depth to his character and I connected with more and more as the movie went on, and the fact that he got to experience loving and looking after a child with Johanna was excellent, the development to their relationship was fantastic and the chemistry between Tom and Helena was fantastic, their father/daughter relationship felt authentic and beautiful, the movie also effectively built tension, the action scenes and the more focused conflict on racism and changing parts of society built the tension very well making the movie slowly get better and better.My final few positives would be the fantastic script, the emotional weight and the emotional and powerful ending. The movie for the most part had a fantastic script, the dialogue was fantastic and powerful, and the script as a whole was well structured, fantastically written and conveyed its themes with depth and emotion. Expanding on my previous comment the movie had a lot of emotional weight, Learning more about Tom Hank's character you really felt emotionally connected to the movie and his character, there was a lot of personnel and deep scenes with his character that were very moving. My final point is the powerful and emotional ending, the movie made an excellent choice with Kyle taking on Johanna as his daughter, it was powerfully written logical and was very moving to watch.Overall, despite News of the world having a fairly poor first half with issues with its pacing and conflict for the characters, News of the world is moving, tense, powerfully acted and has a great message. Showing us that Tom Hanks has still got it and Helena Zengel is an actress to keep an eye on.

Review title: This is a Well Told Great Story
Review_body: Veteran of the Civil War and Non-Fiction Storyteller, Captain Kidd (Tom Hanks) agrees to take 10-yr old Johanna (Helena Zengel) to her biological aunt and uncle. The journey will be 400 miles long and dangerous for both of them. Johanna does not trust Captain Kidd and doesn't want to go.Captain Kidd goes from town to town and reads the latest news stories from newspapers he gathers and tells the town folk what is happening in their world as he understands they are too busy to read newspapers. He finds Johanna on the road and knows she was captured by and lived with the Kiowa Indians. She speaks no English. He takes her to the nearest Army Camp and is told the Indian Agent won't be back for quite a while and he can wait for the Agent or take her to her aunt and uncle himself and that's what he decides to do. Keeping in mind that during his 4-years in the war, he had left his wife in San Antonio and needs to get back to her.To be sure they encounter some bad guys along the trail that want to buy the girl and they sort of get captured by Mr. Farley (Thomas Francis Murphy) and his gang who want to make a new town along the way. Notables: Mare Winningham as Doris Boudlin, a friend of Captain Kidd and she tells him he needs to get back to his wife in San Antonio; Michael Angelo Covina as Mr Almay who wants to buy Johanna; Fred Hechinger as John Calley, who was in Mr. Farley's camp and he gives Captain Kidd his gun for protection; Neil Sandilands as Mr. Leonberger, Johanna's uncle; Winsome Brown as Mrs. Leonberger, Johanna's aunt.Tom Hanks as Captain Kidd was superb as usual. An Oscar for him? Hmmmm....... Young star Helena Zengel as Johanna performed exceptionally well and we appreciated not having her spout English at the end of the movie.My DVD died when Captain Kidd left Johanna with her aunt and uncle and last I saw was him riding away. This couldn't be the end so I started the DVD all over again and FF to where Captain Kidd was riding away. It worked as the story continued and shows him going to San Antonio to see his wife.What happens after Captain Kidd goes to San Antonio to see his wife is something that movies sometimes surprise the hell out of all of us. All I can say is Kudos, kudos and kudos again. I would like to see this movie nominated for Best Picture and hope it gets it. (10/10)Violence: Yes. His performance is flawless, though it's not the kind of role that brings awards much like his previous work with Greengrass, Captain Phillips, should have. This has its tense moments and it actions scenes, but much of it is quiet, subtle and touching. The young girl is played by a German actress, Helena Zengel, and she is terrific with never a false move. I grew up on westerns and they are rarely of interest to me anymore, but this is one of the ones that is. It's a simple story, exceedingly well told and filmed that takes place in a time, 1870, that in some ways indicates how little we have changed.

The story of a young girl orphaned, displaced and disowned, on a journey she doesn't want o be on to a destination she doesn't know.The state of Texas, in its succession from the union and role in the confederacy, is a physical representation of this dislocation, a very real ideological limbo within which the film is set.There is a pervading sense of loss, lost family, languages, culture and identity. On the one hand we have Johanna, an innocent swept up in the events around her over which she has little control. And on the other we have Geoffrey, a man who has lost everything who finds a sense of purpose in Johanna's plight.In this story we see that the United States wasn't created at the signing of the Declaration of Independence, but in the savage and unrelenting destruction of different cultures and identities. The unforgiving process of rebirth and renew that the characters are travelling a straight path through.The plot follows this transition from the old European (German speaking) settlers through the post-war struggle not only in their search for a new sense of place, but in the new United States journey on its path to a new identity.This film is unrelenting in its depiction of the harsh realities of life in that time. Death, murder, exploitation and suffering. But among its darkest moment there is hope and a belief that there is a promised land.As well told as this story is it does suffer from a rather pedestrian pace. While technically this is a great piece of film making many may find the relative lack of action difficult to deal with.Some outstanding performances, particularly from Helena Zengal, could see an Oscar nomination or two.

Review title: Ominous, hardscrabble western cobbled together across the Texas landscape
Review_body: Tom Hanks is a 19th century newsman who reads newspaper stories to townsfolk in Texas. On his route of numerous locations, he comes across a young German-born girl who has been living under the care of native Americans who have been slaughtered. He takes it upon himself as her new guardian to escort her across the countryside to safety in the hope of finding her a new home. Along the way, they achieve an expected bond as two lonely souls in a treacherous world of danger of adversity.Hanks is great as always, as the film is told from his weary, anguished eyes. But newcomer Helena Zengel steals the film from right underneath him with a mesmerizing performance as a young girl traumatized by personal tragedy, untrusting of the world around her and just beginning to learn her communication. Together, they bring this rugged journey to life. Director Paul Greengrass makes a vivid recreation of 19th century American wilderness, a land of difficult terrain and occasionally bitter climate. Through it all, it becomes a battle for survival for both the old man and the child he is protecting. An old school tale of American grit, this one is expertly crafted and highly recommended.

I'm a big fan of Paul Greengrass and Tom Hanks, so I was looking forward to this 19th-century Western. Based on the book of the same name, it tells the story of a Civil War veteran, Capt. Kidd (Hanks) who now serves as a news-teller in Texas. He must bring a young girl, Johanna, to her aunt and uncle. The film is skillfully well-made and leisurely paced, as its tone feels almost lyrical. Its western setting is depicted as harsh and realistic, but still unique and powerful. The film's cinematography of 19th-century north Texas is absolutely impeccable. After "Nomadland," it's the best cinematography of the year. From gorgeous wide shots of prairies and canyons and mountains to detailed sets of important towns at the time such as Wichita Falls, the shots look sublime throughout the film.While the film's pacing is slow, it never feels too slow by any means. In fact, such leisurely pacing feels appropriate to the more lyrical tone of the film--almost like a more gritty version of a ballad. Even though the film is obviously very tonally different from Greengrass' other films, such as the original Bourne trilogy and "Captain Phillips," Greengrass is still able to build up lots of suspense at appropriate times over the course of the film--such as a scene when Capt. Kidd and Johanna must out-maneuver a gang of outlaws, a bumpy and dangerous stagecoach ride, and a desert storm. The emotional core between Kidd and Johanna is very well done, and the performances are very strong. Hanks does a great job showing a range of both charisma and grit in the role, and the young actress who plays Johanna is superb. My only criticism of the film was that the film could have developed Kidd and Johanna better as characters, although the limited dialogue between the two of them (as Johanna does not speak English) may be one of the reasons why character development within the scenes they are both together in can sometimes be a bit limited. Otherwise, this is a gritty yet gorgeous Western made with passion and talent. Gladly recommended. 8/10

An interesting story bogged down by repetitiveness. Tom Hanks is still great as always. He always puts a lot into each of his roles that makes each of his characters stand out from one another with this one being a reluctant father figure who chooses to help those in need. The direction by Paul Greengrass is great. I haven't seen much of his work but I'm interested in seeing what else he can do besides this and Captain Philips. Both of which Tom Hanks starred in. Helena Zengel is good at points and weak in others so I can't praise her performance nor can I bash it. This has an interesting concept of a Civil War Captain who travels from town to town reading the news to people stepping outside of his comfort zone to help someone in need. I think this film did a great job at showing the unrest in 1880s Texas. The film shows the tension between the people of Texas and the Union forces stationed there. It also does a good job at making you feel for some of the characters especially Hanks' character. The cinematography is also great. Greengrass does an incredible job at showing off these great landscapes with each shot feeling a little more different than the last. My big issue with this film comes down to its repetitiveness, pacing, and slow descent into boredom. There is a cool action set piece at the beginning but after that point, the film starts to throw similar situations of peril one after the other. After a while, you start to say to yourself "Haven't we already seen this before?" It doesn't help that the pacing is awful at times with some scenes going on for way to long while others are cut way too short like the scene where a town is basically controlled by outlaws. We spend so little time there and it was a very interesting scenario that is cut away from. I also take issue with the resolution of the film being not great. Without spoiling the film, we see what happens and you think that that's it but then the movie goes on for another 25-30 minutes and it's really boring aside from one 3 minute long scene with Hanks. It should have ended where I thought it was gonna end. If you like Tom Hanks or Western movies then you might get something out of this but you can wait until it comes out on DVD, Blu-Ray, or rental to watch it.

Review title: Touching tale about loss and "Home" in the West...
Review_body: First things first, 13yr old Helena Zengel who plays Johanna, is absolutely outstanding! Her performance alongside a wonderful, as always, Tom Hanks is simply stunning, in some scenes she almost overshadows him.That aside, this is a slow burn tail of a retired Captain Kidd who travels around the old west reading the news from town to town. His usual routine is completely thrown though when he discovers a young girl (pale skin, blonde hair) who had obviously been abducted and then raised by Native Indians, but is now abandoned. This is young Johanna.The story follows them as they try and make their way across country to some people who could be Johannas relatives. Their relationship is sweet to watch, and Hanks portrays a paternal caring that seems to come so naturally in many of the roles he plays. Zengel plays a young girl unsure of herself, and split between two cultures so very well. They both learn from each other as the journey goes on.Ultimately the story is about each of them suffering loss, with the other actually filling the hole that their loss creates. Johanna has no parents, Kidd has no family. They have both lost something, but together they find their "home".Beautifully shot, with a slow elegant pace, it doesn't fall prey to any of the Wild West stereotypes, but the danger they encounter along the way is all to believable.Sometimes it was almost a little too slow, and a lot of the nights scenes were so dark it was hard to see... but a very enjoyable movie nevertheless. Beautiful story, beautifully portrayed by a wonderful cast.

Review title: Extra, Extra... Superior Talent Turns in Pedestrian Effort
Review_body: It wasn't unreasonable for me to be properly excited for News of the World. The newest Hollywood western, and the first new theatrical release in about five months that felt worth taking a trip to the cinema to see, News of the World had two big talents on board: star Tom Hanks and director Paul Greengrass. If there were anyone to put a little blind faith in, it would be two men behind some of the great films of the last three decades. The Greengrass-Hanks pairing, so fruitful in Captain Phillips, is, however, pretty barren in their second outing. News of the World is a considerable disappointment from these two great artists.Based on the novel by Paulette Jiles, News of the World is simplistic to a fault. Tom Hanks is Captain Jefferson Kyle Kidd, a Civil War veteran who currently makes a living reading newspapers to busy townspeople in a sort of theatrical storytime across the country. Kidd stumbles one day upon an orphaned German girl named Johanna (Helena Zengel). Johanna was taken in by Kiowa Indians as a youngin' and has completely assimilated to their ways. Kidd figures out that she needs to be transported to her surviving German relatives, and Kidd... takes her there. That's the story for ya. Cross country road trips are not new to the Western genre, but Jiles' story strikes me as unusually thin. The attempts to create tension along the way are woeful. At two separate points along the trail, two separate groups of men show up out of nowhere just to announce to Kidd, in so many words, that they will be the bad guys for the next bit. Obviously, these characters aren't the important ones. Kidd and Johanna are.Their relationship is the centerpiece, and I can't really fault it. Hanks, the ever-reliable professional, rolls up his sleeves and says his lines with conviction as he always does. Zengel has an appropriate look; she isn't an annoying little cutie or smug growler as so many movie kids are these days, and she gives a good performance. I might even call it impressive. A scene or two or three of their growing bond hits home. These are the moments when you can see that director Greengrass kind of knows what he's doing.Elsewhere, things aren't as pretty. Greengrass' reputation is with visceral shaky cameras and documentary-style filmmaking. That's not what News of the World needs, and it's not exactly what the movie is. But Greengrass is no hack. He's also one of the preeminent masters of immediacy and excitement. Those qualities are what I miss. That is what is glaringly lacking with the approach he brings to News of the World. This isn't a United 93-esque docudrama, brimming with that sort of intensity. News of the World is a traditional story and it is shot like a traditional "movie". Just not as painterly or carefully composed as some. However, the only thing that directorial restraint creates is a limp, boring visual look. I think I would have respected a full lean into documentary authenticity here, or conversely, a full lean into John Ford-ian grandeur, but what we get instead is a hesitant attempt to be a little (but not too much) different from Greengrass' other works. For the most part, it's soft-focused, claustrophobic and close-up heavy, with only the occasional drone shot to highlight some dull Texan exteriors. Weaksauce. There's a way to envelope an audience in verisimilitude that Greengrass has perfected in his oeuvre (make it tight, immediate, suspenseful), and there's a way to do it on a giant canvas (look at the pictorial magnificence of something like Dances with Wolves). Greengrass and his cinematographer do neither with News of the World. You can't just point a camera at a beautiful landscape and have it transport the viewer there.Nothing grabs in News of the World. Tom Hanks is out there doing his thing, but is Captain Kidd really an interesting character? Is Hanks' performance anything special? No. The story is blah, the filmmaking is blah. It's very strange to see Paul Greengrass so lackadaisical. He seems uninterested in the material, and why shouldn't he be? The material is uninteresting. But still, there was something to salvage here. I mentioned that father-daughter relationship. It works on its own, in those individual scenes. But I trusted these filmmakers to come at it with a considered point of view. To put some kind of spin on it. To find something worthwhile in there. That didn't happen. What a shame.57/100

Review title: Atmospheric and paternal, but a bit too stale at the same time
Review_body: Paul Greengrass' News of the World isn't for everyone to enjoy. With a slow-paced but substantive storyline of a travelling news reader and a little girl circumstantially left in his care, this movie shows on screen a story of kin, compassion and trust.News of the World requires from the audience a lot of patience, and fairly does reward it at the end. But it still doesn't discount the almost tiresome journey the audience had to take to get there. Despite what might seem like me insinuating, I don't think I would ever use the word "boring" to describe it... just that it's a little too slow to have kept my attention all the way.Technically however, the movie is quite strong. With amazing landscapes photographed in its magnificence, to the well crafted world of the 1800s, to the sounds, and costumes and everything that crafts a movie to visual brilliance... News of the World scores perfectly.A nice movie, but not compulsory.

Review title: An Unconventional Western - Which Is Why It's Great
Review_body: Movie goers who want their pacing to merely be a short time until the next fight should look elsewhere. Accept a movie on its own terms and stop projecting. If you go in wanting the same thing as always, no it is not here. If you have patience and keep the same curiosity about the characters as the narrative, you'll get your pay off. And then some. Their humanity is what makes them interesting and compelling, not when the next shoot out is going to happen.Not every Western needs to conform to the same formula. This adaptation of a fantastic novel by Paulette Jiles takes that to heart. Conflicts are not solely physical or mortal. The past is the most formidable foe for the characters here. Forcing each into their own groove that's hard to divorce.In its own way, it's harder on the characters than most westerns. It's a beautiful way to further depict this overdone time period meaningfully. It helps that the acting, script, cinematography, shot compositions, and colour palette are all excellent as well. One of the more compelling offerings from the genre in some time.

Review title: Escorting a 10 year old girl to her parents in year 1870
Review_body: Captain Kidd a civil war veteran makes a livelihood reading out newspaper stories to the gathering of people of the town much to their delight. For this the Captain gets a dime a person and this is what he does from town to town.During one such trip he comes across a 10 year old girl Helena in an accident site. Since the authorities don't take responsibility, escorting this 10 year old helpless girl ( Helena Zengel) to her biological parents across the Texas plains in year 1870 becomes the self imposed mission of Captain Kidd ( Tom Hanks). This makes an absorbing film as both man and girl face and overcome natural ( sand storm) and man made ( gunfight with hoodlums ) obstacles. Both make it through the wild terrain through sheer grit and courage. He also carries her in his arms for some distance when she is overcome with fatigue, hunger and thirst.Director Paul Greengrass has done a commendable job in developing the narrative in a gripping way. Particularly impressive is the way he has handled Helena Zengel as he brings out her tension and anxiety realistically. Tom Hanks is brilliant as usual as Captain Kidd, where he fits in the character perfectly. The director is helped by the superb cinematography of Dariusz Wolski as he skilfully captures the inhospitable and ruthless terrain.

Review title: Six Stars for Tom Hanks and for the final Fifteen Minutes
Review_body: I'm awarding Six Stars for Tom Hanks and for the film's final Fifteen Minutes. It's impossible not to appreciate Hanks' work; a melancholy Texan who travels the West reading newspapers to rural townsfolk who otherwise could not receive it. Hanks is terrific in this role; the sound of his voice and his overall manner just pitch perfect for this task.In one such town Hanks' character takes on the responsibility of escorting an orphaned child across Texas to relatives she has never met. Nor do they know she's been orphaned. The road is perilous. And we care about their safety. We like Hanks' news-reader. And his motives are pure.But then ..... The perils the two face seem repetitive. And the speed (or lack of) in dealing with each situation seems to drain the suspense out of the encounters. The film's middle is a tough go for one who wants to make it to the film's finale without dozing off. But somehow, I did.And about the finale. You might see it coming. I did. But still I found it rousing and spirited, and long after I forget the film's flabby mid-section, I'll remember its conclusion. As a good thing.

The federal government cares little for unaccompanied minors, ignorance and bigotry are prevalent across the south, a wealthy man resorts to violence when his grip on power is threatened. Sound at all familiar? Captain Jefferson Kyle Kidd is tasked with escorting a young girl to her sole surviving relatives. Tom Hanks and Helena Zengel produce excellent central performances but the story, such as it is, consists of a series of unrelated stock Western tropes (outlaws, remote township, the elements, Native Americans) with no purpose other than to develop a tenuous relationship between Kidd and Johanna, and that relationship is designed to enable Kidd to finally confront the death of his late wife many years previously. I enjoyed it, but it won't live long in the memory.

Review title: Good ole Western film - nice to see a solid story and great acting/directing
Review_body: I am a big fan of both Paul Greengrass and Tom Hanks yet I was a bit hesitant to watch a movie that is a western with such a simple story. However this film is something that has been lacking in Hollywood for a long time - a good solid script about a day in the life of the Western days without any agenda or spoiling of story telling days and Greengrass delivers. It has a little bit of everything action, heart felt moments and some of the history behind those days of strife and loss, and is beautifully shot in New Mexico even though it claims to be Texas. The new young actress Helena Zengel really does a magnificent job and is almost the star of the film with Tom Hanks as her guardian angel with lots of spectacular moments that remind me of some of older western films like Sergio Leone but with less pinache or loads of actions but a good heart felt film that is quite touching. If you are looking for a solid film that the entire family can watch this is one worth enjoying. A solid 8 and looking forward to more films with Helena.

Sometimes I watch films just for the actors. Tom Hanks always delivers what he promises, now my interest was even greater because of young Helena Zengel and her Golden Globe nomination, although I don't really like westerns. As a result, this is not an outstanding film, but nevertheless the Hanks/Zengel team is worthwhile. Especially the still unknown German actress, who plays a girl of German descent who grew up among the Kiowa, will snatch up big roles, I assume. She manages to captivate the audience without many words. Whether this is actually due to her acting or simply to her charisma will be seen in later films. Nothing about her performance is exaggerated, there is no false pathos, no grand gestures. And Tom Hanks fits in very well, as he is known for his subtle art anyway. If you like rather quiet films that tell a quiet story, you will feel at home here.

Tom Hanks has to be the most reliable actor in Hollywood, I haven't seen him give a bad performance ever. In this film, which could almost be labelled a road trip he is a seasoned old war veteran delivering news of the world to the pioneers of the west. These scenes are some of the most interesting in the film. But his travels round the state of Texas are mostly filled with events of the sort we are all too familiar with, in the western genre. You know the sort of thing,,, gun battles, double dealing, there is even a dust storm thrown in for good measure.
I don't think Hanks has ever been in a western before, not that it matters because the real richness of this story comes from the relationship between him and a homeless little girl. The film's opening sequence sets the scene: he inadvertently teams up with a homeless little girl who has witnessed a horrifying event. She is traumatized and sticks to him like glue. Being only ten years old, and him being a kind man of honour, they team up and find solace in each other's company. You can of course see the ending coming in this particular story and their relationship, interesting though it is, somehow never fizzes into vibrant life. The direction is slow paced, and the Texas scenery doesn't enhance the story as much as one would like. I found myself wondering what John Ford would have done with it. The pace would have been much quicker, and the dialogue would have made you bristle to listen to every word. It's not a bad film by any means, perhaps one of the main problems is that the little girl, Johannna, steals every scene from Hanks, and audiences are not used to that.
I could not help but compare it with True Grit, which had a similar theme and was filled with compelling characters and a story that bowled along at a quicker pace. What is likely, however, is that young Helena Eigel will become a star in her own right one day.

Review title: One Of the More Realistic Westerns
Review_body: The story is about a person who takes donations for the task of reading news papers to a small, rural audience in post Civil War Texas. The news reader, Capt. Kidd, is played by Tom Hanks, of course. Early in the film, as Kidd is traveling a trail from one town to another, he encounters a young girl, Johanna. He learns that she was held captive by Kiowa Indians since almost infancy. In fact, she knows no English, only Kiowa and traces of German. Kidd needs to take her to her aunt and uncle, which are all that is left of her kin. The trip is several hundred miles and will take weeks. While en route they encounter a number of dangerous episodes and assorted bad guys, which draws Kidd and the little girl closer together emotionally.The movie reminded me a bit of the more recent version of True Grit. One thing that has caught my attention in recent decades is how good child actors are. That wasn't the case up until maybe 1980. The little girl, played by Helena Zengel, was very good in her role. In fact, all of the performances were good. Anyway, the action is not steady. There are down periods. But that's okay. The motive is not another Die Hard, after all. I gave News of the World a solid 7. I could have gone 8 and not felt I was being too generous.

Review title: Strong performance and visuals bring an familiar tale to life
Review_body: A western cowboy era movie starring Tom Hanks. Cowboy type movies are sort of a dying genre nowadays but it was interesting to see legendary actor Tom Hanks star in one. Additionally, it was being directed by Paul Greengrass who directed some of the best Jason Bourne movies (and worst) and Captain Phillips which also starred Tom Hanks. The summary is "Five years after the end of the Civil War, Capt. Jefferson Kyle Kidd (Tom Hanks) crosses paths with a 10-year-old girl (Helena Zengel) taken by the Kiowa people. Kidd agrees to escort the child across the harsh and unforgiving plains of Texas. However, the long journey soon turns into a fight for survival as the travelling companions encounter danger at every turn -- both human and natural". So does this movie manage to achieve its goal or fall into the empty desert?The biggest praise has got to go to Tom Hanks and Helena Zengel performance of the main duos. Tom Hanks gives a subtle weariness and melancholy to his character while still containing compassion that feels genuine. Helena is a child actor so there was some scepticism from me but she delivers with some emotional and even heart-warming performances. The chemistry between the two actors is evident which is why it was such an enormous pleasure to watch both of them. Watching the relationship between these two characters develop from just strangers to that of a family is touching. The scenes where it is just both of them are some of the most enjoyable scenes in the movie and this is thanks to the strong performance from both of them. The supporting cast is really good as well and deliver an effective performance for their representative characters.The movie contains some great cinematography that makes the movie aesthetically striking and gorgeous visually. This is quite a feat considering that a majority of the movie is set in set in some empty fields but the cinematographer, Dariusz Wolski, pulls it off. It is also complemented by great set and costume design that looks authentic and pulls you into the era the movie is set in. The music score by James Newton Howard is also really strong and is effective in representing the scenes. There are some action scenes in the movie and they are very tense with no shaky cam that is seen from the Bourne movies. For the most part, it is a character-driven story but the action scenes are really good when they occur.However, the story is very predictable and even cliche. There is not a lot of originality in this movie and the story is pretty much a beat for a beat tale that has been told so many times before. You can probably guess what is going to happen for the majority of this movie. The heartwarming scenes while done effectively are also things that have been done in previous movies or games. You will see these scenes and feel like you seen them before. There are also some pacing issues with this movie as it can slow at times near the beginning and near the end. Some scenes didn't add much and could have been cut to improve the pacing.Overall, the movie may be very familiar but it is entertaining nonetheless. Thanks to the strong performances and the visually pleasing design of the movie, it is still able to keep you glued to watching it. Under all of its layer, there is a lovely drama that conveys a meaningful message which honestly might be the news the world needs right now.

Many expected to see duels in the wild wild west. On the contrary, this film shows the reality and the harsh life was in those days. Review title: Hanks deserves better than this unoriginal screenplay

The odd couple theme is not new, nor the storyline with them drawing closer and closer. The ending is predictable. What made me shrug my shoulders the most is the random and mindless malevolence of the baddies as they pursue the travellers and deservedly perish in the gunfire. To say this is unmotivated is putting it mildly. It's just an excuse for the obligatory gunfight. If only they had the courage to leave this out. The other material has more realism and pathos. I would really mark this film down if it wasn't for Tom Hanks, who carries it with the power of his performance. The girl is not bad I suppose - at least she is in no way cute or lovable, and that helps to keep the sentimentality to a low level. Special mention must go to the fat horses, which apparently can be ridden or driven day after day without ever needing to be fed! My criticisms do not suggest the film is not watchable or entertaining, it's just that in retrospect it is depressingly clear that it is derivative and unoriginal.

Review title: A well-told western that falls short of being great
Review_body: Paul Greengrass and Tom Hanks have followed up their 2013 box-office hit Captain Phillips with another collaboration. In News of the World, Hanks plays a captain for the seventh time in his career, this time in a wild western. In the aftermath of the Civil War, he is a war veteran in charge of bringing the news to the people. On his journey across Texas, he meets a left-behind orphan from the Kiowa tribe and makes it his mission to provide her with a safe living. In the process, the two build a special relationship.Tom Hanks is, as always, a banker in the lead role of Captain Jefferson Klyde Kidd. It is the down-to-earth and empathetic nature that his characters often have about them. Hanks gives them the final touch with his great charisma and warm-heartedness. Even though in this case there is nothing wrong with his performance, one has the feeling that Hanks only deliberately chooses such characters. It would be exciting to see him slip into other roles once again. In the end, one even has the feeling that he could have got that bit more out of the character Jefferson Klyde Kidd. Helena Zengel does a great job for her young age as the Indian girl Johanna. Again, the role is quite similar to the one in Systemcrasher, the film that brought Zengel international fame. She is taciturn and once she opens up, she is either quick-tempered or emotionally confused. The chemistry between the two characters is ultimately what makes the film. It works flawlessly and shines especially when they teach each other words in their native languages. They build a father-daughter relationship with each other that you buy over the full length.Basically, News of the World is a solid film that does justice to the Western genre. The plot contains much that we have already seen to excess, but gains its own appeal through the chemistry of the two leads and an exciting shootout scene towards the middle of the film. Greengrass must hope, however, that viewers are still with him at all up to that point. Because the first 30-40 minutes are extremely slow and drag on. Westerns are often built up rather leisurely, but here they have taken too much time with the build-up of tension. With the aforementioned shootout scene, the film acquires more depth, which is reflected in the dialogues between the protagonists, beautiful images of the desert landscape and a very smooth accompanying score. The ending gets under the skin a lot on the one hand, but is too predictable on the other. News of the World is generally not a film that goes for surprising twists. It's a rather semi-brutal western, with decent performances and good technical skills - but that's all it is.

Review title: Well done story reminiscent of a real life story
Review_body: In this film, Tom Hanks plays Captain Jefferson Kyle Kidd, a Civil War veteran who makes his living traveling from town to town in Texas and reading various newspaper accounts to groups of townspeople for a dime a head.Between towns, he finds a body executed and a young girl abandoned. The papers found near the body identify the girl as Johanna, and that she had been kidnapped and adopted by the Kiowa 6 years before. She speaks only Kiowa, having lost her native German. Somehow, Captain Kidd finds himself trying to return her to what surviving family she has, 400 miles away (across the plains of West Texas, a difficult and dangerous journey).I won't write anymore about the plot except to say that it is well done, and that it tells multiple stories well.I mentioned that this is reminiscent of a real life story - that of Cynthia Ann Parker, kidnapped and adopted by the Comanche in 1836. Cynthia Parker ended up choosing being Comanche over returning to the Parkers (a prominent Texas family). The character of Johanna in this film does an excellent job of illustrating the cultural no-man's land that capture and adoption created. If you are wondering why this novel was chosen rather than the story of Cynthia Ann Parker?One, the story of Cynthia Ann Parker has sort of already been done (although not realistically) - The Searchers starring John Wayne. Second, Cynthia Ann Parker chose to remain a Comanche, she didn't return to live in the world of Texans. Third, the people who searched for these children and to return them to their families were often not very reputable individuals.Kidnapping and adopting children was common among the Natives of North America, especially the plains tribes. It is possible that their life on horseback contributed to a low birthrate. Children adopted were raised just as if they had been born into the tribe, and some even rose to high status. An example is Quanah Parker (the last war chief of the Comanche) - the son of Cynthia Ann Parker.What most impressed me about this film was Helena Zengel's performance as a German child who was kidnapped and adopted by the Kiowa and then recovered 6 years later.

Of the films I have seen this year, News of the World is easily the best. The premise is interesting --- the protagonist (Hanks) makes his living from his literacy, obtaining newspapers and reading them to far-flung audiences assembled in a series of towns along his route in the post-Civil War South (mostly Texas). He is a military veteran, affording him the skills necessary to survive in the postwar landscape, which can be extremely dangerous at times. He is on a mission, reluctantly taken at first, to return a German-American girl to her surviving relatives after first her parents, and then her adoptive Kiowa parents, had been killed.While the Kiowa are treated sympathetically, opportunities were available, but missed, to tell the story from their perspective as well. They are literally presented as ghostly figures on the periphery of the landscape in all but one scene. I live in an area with a high population of indigenous people, and I guess I'm used to hearing our first people's points of view on most topics (I emphasize the plural --- it's not just one viewpoint), so the omission was noticeable.However, the film stands on its own as a great achievement, even if much more could have been done to tell the Kiowa story. Helena Zengel plays the twice-orphaned girl, and is convincing in portraying a confused and ambivalent approach to her ever-changing guardians. The film finishes by developing her character further, and in retrospect, that is actually what this film is about!

It's directed by Paul Greengrass so the question arises; which Paul Greengrass are we getting? Is it the urgent, intense, investigative Greengrass of the latter Bourne movies, and Green Zone, or is this the slower, more observant, character study of, say, Captain Phillips?I's the latter. Greengrass and Hanks are interested in showing us a man, fundamentally decent, but battered by his experience; by war, by life, and how he travels the American frontier just trying to get by.Hanks plays Captain Kidd, a former soldier who earns his living by travelling from town to far-off town and reading from newspapers both local and national about the goings-on elsewhere. The masses, illiterate and cut off by the vast distances of the American west, pay to hear him read aloud, and learn about the goings on in the world.Western movies are so inextricably bound up in the American myth, "how the west was won", that it would be difficult not to see this as an allegory for America even if we weren't being subtly pointed in that direction. We see how the populace can be riled up by unwelcome news about the Federal government, or how they can be inspired to band together through stories of overcoming adversity. The masses can be shaped by (fake) news, and they can be set free by the seeing the best in each other. It's not an especially complicated message, but it sure is a timely one.The lead role role is so fundamentally latter-day Hanks-ian, so of a piece with other recent roles of his such as the aforementioned Captain Phillips, or those in, say, Sully, and Bridge of Spies that it's hard not to grant some authorial voice to him as well as to Greengrass in the making of this movie. It's just a shame Hanks doesn't seem willing to imbue these characters with more complexity than that. They are good. They do the right thing. That is really all there is. Hanks' flirtation with the dark side, as in Road to Perdition, is behind him. There's a great appetite for these movies, and I'm not immune (far from it) to the charms of Hanks being the world's reassuring movie-dad but it does leave the story in a far more predictable place.Greengrass and Hanks show us Kidd travelling through a world near broken, and unable to face its past when he finds an abandoned child and makes it his mission to bring her home. You can absolutely guess where this is going, and you won't be wrong.That's the pleasure of a movie like this - you know exactly what it's doing, and you watch expert craftsmen take you there, sure in the knowledge that they won't drop the ball.And they don't. But ultimately it's all a little safe, a little too conventional to mark it out as something more than capable, efficient, well-made,But that's not to condemn this movie. The bright spots pulled me in. Hanks delivers a solid performance. Helena Zengel is a delight as the spirited child Kidd takes under his wing. It's gorgeous to look at; both the grandeur of the wide open spaces, and the flickering candlelight and shadows of the night time scenes.It's a film you would be delighted to come across one rainy Sunday afternoon, but which no one will ever claim as their favourite movie.

Review title: Tough message, but Tom Hanks is great.
Review_body: I did enjoy watching this film on Amazon Prime's early release because Tom Hanks was excellent. But it's hard to watch how horrible the people were depicted in the post Civil War Texas. You have a lynching. You have greedy capitalists who destroy the buffalo and abuse their workers. You have evil men at every turn down the road. You have a little girl who just wants to go back to her Indian kidnappers because she likes being an Indian. Several times, I felt like the best thing for her would be to grant her wish to return to them instead of subjecting her to the American settlers. The little girl describes how everything is connected in nature in a big circle of life, while Tom Hanks says that Americans just go in a straight line and look ahead. The movie infers that there is no time to appreciate nature for the settlers. One character even says that there is no time for stories. He needs to focus on working the fields.This is not a Clint Eastwood film like Unforgiven where I found myself rooting for the most evil man in the West to kill Little Bill. The film hints that Tom Hanks' character may not be a great guy, but I never saw proof of this. I just saw someone who did his duty during the war. This is more of a story of how horrid people of Texas treated each other and the native population. It shows the resentment of the townsfolk for the Northern soldiers and the Northern President after the war ended. It was interesting how the army took away the Texans' guns and only allowed them buck shot weapons. It's a story of how the natural resources were abused with an awful scene showing an endless field of skinned buffalos.Tom Hanks is very believable as an aging man just scraping out a simple living reading the news. I thought the film was shot with a gritty reality in mind. The gun fight scenes did remind me a bit of Unforgiven in the way that it's not like Hollywood depicts when it's real people fighting for their lives. It showed us a dangerous road and an unforgiving terrain. It was worth watching, but it's a very tough message to stomach even if that's the reality of those times.

No, not the long-extinct British tabloid closed down for hacking celebrity answering machines, but a rather fine western staring everyone's favourite nice guy, Tom Hanks. Here, he travels across a believably authentic setting of 1870's America to deliver a long-lost girl to her only surviving relatives: the trouble is, she was taken by Indians when her family was slaughtered and only speaks their language after spending years in their company. This, as you can imagine, creates some problems in communications along the way...Tom Hanks is great in his role as the child's sole protector, who has a murky past of his own... but what did you expect? He kinda has a well-earned reputation for top performances. The real revelation is playing the young lady, who despite hardly uttering a word in English says so much with expressions and gestures alone in an incredibly emotional tour-de-force. If she isn't nominated for an Oscar later this year, let's just say there better be some pretty strong competition.Don't go in expecting anything very gritty... aside from a couple of tense shootouts, this is strictly a tale of two aspiring outcasts who find each other and bond during a long journey in the Wild West. Which is fine, as anyone expecting something along the lines of a C Eastwood epic needs to check their expectations at the door. Just sit back, relax and lose yourself in a genuinely moving and captivating flick.Doesn't sound too hard, does it? 7/10
