I enjoyed this film. The growing relationship between the man and the girl is sweet and interesting. The film is somewhat episodic as they experience difficulties on their trip. My big gripe is that the part of Texas they are traveling through looks nothing like this. Many films are made in New Mexico because of financial benefits that Texas doesn't provide. "No Country for old Men", "Hell or High Water", and this film all look great, but "News of the World" was supposed to be in North Texas down through Central East Texas. The Dallas area is rolling black soil grassland with numerous rivers and creeks surrounded by large woods. It's farmland famous for cotton production. It's not desert. The Eastern half of Texas is Wooded with streams. Before cotton, cattle, or oil the first major cash crop to new settlers was lumber. San Antonio is on the Eastern edge of the Hill country, where there are hills separated by valleys with rock bottom, clear running streams, the most scenic part of the state. West Texas is dry desert, but that isn't where this film is supposed to be taking place. From John Ford filming in Monument valley, to Lonesome Dove, Texas is too often depicted unrealistically, geographically. It's annoying.

Whilst not that original in storyline, it is beautifully filmed and scored, and thoughtfully directed by Paul Greengrass. Overall, an enjoyable and absorbing if sometimes old fashioned western - and there's nothing wrong with that.

She is going to be a real star.There are a few things that bring this film off of a higher rating. 1) It's a bit predictable. 2) There is some emotional blackmailing of the viewer (no spoilers)However, this film should be seen for a wide range of strengths. 1) It looks GREAT! The brilliant town scenes and landscapes reminded me of Sergio Leone's masterpiece "Once Upon a Time in the West" - that's how good it is! 2) The acting is strong. 3) It's about time America faced some of it's past. 4) The music is good.Easy to see why this film has Oscar Nominations!Overall - a good film. Would look amazing on the big screen. Good story - great photography.

Texas. The Civil War ended not too long ago. Vitriol, eerily reminiscent of modern day, is everywhere. Union soldiers observing gatherings and patrolling roads are an unnerving presence, proven useless when actually needed. Tom Hanks is playing a reluctant hero - a role he perfected many times over. Here he is Captain Kidd, a former Confederate officer now making a living by traveling from town to town reading newspapers to the local folk. We don't learn until the end what it was that drove him onto that treacherous path. And it was good to have that intrigue. It would have been interesting if the film also looked into how a man of such decency and intelligence was able to lead Confederate soldiers for 4 years. How did he come to hold views so different from those he was living among?Captain Kidd's already dangerous travels get a lot more dangerous when he stumbles upon a 10 year old orphan girl named Johanna played by a fantastic young German actress Helena Zengel. Johanna was kidnapped by Kiowa Indians as a toddler and raised by them as one of their own. Her biological parents were killed. And now she was orphaned and kidnapped again by people who surely thought they were rescuing her. She is to be taken "home" to relatives she's never met. Except, there's no one to get her there for months. Captain Kidd quickly realizes that he has no choice - otherwise she simply won't survive.There's nothing particularly earth shattering about News of the World. It's a very well made road trip film, following a common formula - two damaged souls who don't speak the same language, figuratively and, in this case, literally, gradually becoming each other's saviors. But I couldn't take my eyes off the screen as I watched the pair battle dangerous people and elements. The camerawork created a wonderful sense of immersion. Whether it's a stunning visual of Indian families on the opposite side of the river walking along the cliff in the rain like phantoms or gorgeous, sunny, yet terrifying landscape the characters are riding through - the movie pulls you in and doesn't let go.

'News of the World' isn't a bad movie as such. But nor is it a good one, either. There is very little, besides the cinematography, that really grabs you an draws you into the film. Apparently the two main lead characters bond, but I'm not quite sure when and how, because director Paul Greengrass doesn't really want to let us in on it. There's very little chemistry between the two main protagonists that gives you reason to believe that they connect with each other deep down, and not much that really made me relate and connect to the characters and their situation either, meaning that as a result, I didn't care about them. It's a shame, because I was really hoping to enjoy this movie, not least as I like westerns in general. But I just found my attention wandering on far too many occasions during this one to enjoy and recommend it.

Well, first off, Tom Hanks is the star of the movie. So, yeah, acting is pretty top-notch as you would expect. Everyone is quite good in their roles, especially Tom Hanks. Outside of that, the movie is kinda mixed, but one thing it does very well is character development. We start the film with the girl, Johanna only being able to speak Kiowa, and Captain Kidd (Hanks' character) trying to speak to her with German and English. Getting near the end they're speaking a mix of Kiowa, German, and English to each other as they are learning from each other. Heck, even outside of language they learn from each other, such as Johanna teaching Kidd to use money inside of bullets to kill the kidnappers. The strength of the characters and character development is really what the movie relies on, because everything else is kinda meh. I honestly don't remember anything from the score (and film scores are something I pay attention to), I thought a few scenes went on too long, namely, the shootout, and honestly, that whole scene just felt out of place in the movie. Anyway, this movie is good, but not great. Still recommend though. It just depends on how much you care about character development in movies. If you really care, you'll probably like this movie. If not, stay away, this film isn't for you. That's pretty much all this film brings to the table.

She and Tom have great chemistry as they travel on a long road together in a wagon to find her aunt and uncle.
Along the way there is an exiting scene where they are being chased by 3 men who want the girl. Tom and the girl go hiding up in the rocks and have a shoot out with the men...I felt badly for the girl and she played the part so well. You want to see her make it safely to the end of the road trip after everything the poor kid has been through already. I predicted the ending but was glad it turned out the way it did because I found it to be so heartwarming. Definitely reccommended when you get the chance to see it. Tom is good as always. Overall this is not a bad movie, Tom Hanks performance is solid , everything is well shot, the sound is good, photography is good ... but they tried too hard to make a boring movie look good and epic, and that's where everything start falling apart. I can advise you to watch it with low expectations , and yes this may be a movie that will suit many , but not me.

Review title: Nothing new in the Western World
Review_body:
Maybe I was expecting too much from the 2nd collaboration of Greengrass and Hanks, hoping for some kind of reinvention of the Western Genre.
The result is worth watching, but no surprise. Hanks never disappoints, portraying the loneliness of his character almost with too much routine, and child actress Helena Zengel is very promising. But the collection of genre stereotypes here, the clichees of the villains, the shooting sequences, crossing a desert running out of water, the traumas of post civil war (with some references to the divided nation of today) really doesn't do an exceptional movie for me, but just an average one, giving me the feeling I had seen all of this a hundred times before.

Review title: Heartfelt tale of post bellum Texas
Review_body: A story of loss and hope found. Hanks is at his best in this slowly paced heartfelt story of 1870 Texas. An ex-Confederate soldier, an educated man who has lost everything, travelling the roads reading newspapers to the locals. Two strangers, who together face privations and danger, and eventually create a new life as father and daughter.

This movie tells us a story about man Captain Kidd (Tom Hanks) who is traveling from city to city to read newspapers to busy people for ten cents. One day he sees an overturned and mugged waggon at which Captain Kidd finds a little girl who doesn't understand English and he will try to bring her home.This movie was published by Netflix.Movie will acquaint us with Captain Kid and a little girl slowly. Review title: An entertaining and engaging tale of adventure
Review_body: Like many Tom Hanks movies, News of the World presents a scenario that is different from the run of the mill. While it is easy enough to guess how things will turn out, the movie is still very watchable. It can be enjoyed on the surface as a Western story of challenge and survival. It can also be appreciated for exploring issues of community, social responsibilities, personal identity, and so on. That said, sometimes plot elements were just a bit too convenient to keep events headed in the right direction. It would have been more authentic, for instance, had the young girl, Johanna, exhibited more confusion, both in emotion and in communication. But overall, a great movie, well recommended.

When I country needs to be born the midwives appear to facilitate the process. In the nineteenth century, an ex-captain that served on the side of the Union in the American Civil War became a newsman going from city to city to read the newspapers to audiences willing to pay a couple of dimes to know about the stories from distant states and cities. His way is crossed by a little orphan girl under custody of Union with an order to be placed in an indigenous reserve. She is a white girl that has a double orphan destiny. Her parents were killed by indigenous warriors requesting their land back. Later, her indigenous step-parents would be killed by confederate soldiers from Texas. The captain has a mission: to find a place for this girl whose parents are dead already. As a framework to tell the history of Texas state, this well-designed film brings us to observe how complex and painful was the born of the United States of America. A very interesting storyboard with great actors' performances, this film brings a unique story inside history.

First, the positives: The location shots of New Mexico were just beautiful. I only visited there once, in 1974, when I was a Scout hiking Philmont, but the images are etched in my mind as if it were yesterday. The young girl performed well in what must have been a difficult role.But--we've seen this movie before, and we've seen it from Tom Hanks. Consider the following:
1) A man suddenly thrust into single guardianhood (to coin a phrase)--"Sleepless in Seattle"
2) A man on a mission to bring an now-only child home--"Saving Private Ryan"
3) A man who ended up on the wrong side learns valuable life lessons--"A League of Their Own"
There are even non-Tom Hanks references. To wit: A man goes on a road trip with a nearly non-verbal fellow traveler--"Rain Man", although I admit the girl's moments were timely, showed street smarts and a deeply-rooted survival instinct.
Further, even though Tom Hanks' character played a solid man, they still fall back on the "dumb redneck Southerner" stereotype so ingrained in lesser efforts with other characters (Not Mr. Hanks, the men of Erath County). I got the distinct impression that if we moved the story to the present day that we'd see those same characters in jeans, t-shirts, and MAGA caps.I enjoyed the time with my wife on a date, but taken as a whole, I didn't particularly enjoy the movie.

Review title: Not good enough, nor bad enough
Review_body: The movie isnt good enough to be great, but not bad enough to be dismissed. It's an enjoyable movie, and worth a watch if you're in the mood, but not one that can be enthusiastically recommended.I kept expecting some sort of deeper level allegory to come forward as it got closer to the end, but when that didnt happen I thought I'd read some reviews and see if others missed something that I hadnt caught. Unfortunately, the more I read, the more it became apparent that no, I dont think I'd missed anything, the story is just not that deep. It's not a terrible story or anything, there just arent any extra levels that you need to dig for in order to get that umph at the end.One of the key faults to this movie is that it's not truly a western and it's not a completely contemporary story, either. A western is a story where the frontier is as much a character as any of the actors. It needs to be a story that can only happen in the west because of the way it impacts the characters. In News of the World the setting languishes somewhere in between. The characters dont act or portray an honest vision of the people who lived in that place and time. Instead they feel too much like people from some generic reality inserted into a landscape with horses and revolvers. If you were to take this story and retell it in medieval Europe, or feudal Japan, or any other era, other than costuming and sets, you wouldnt have to change anything. So, in short, the frontier only serves as a vehicle to drive the characters from plot point to plot point.An example of this is the people. EVERYONE acts exactly the same in EVERY interaction. The same monotone delivery, the same lifeless expression, the dead-behind-the-eyes look, it's all too much effort to say "look how ruined these people are, instead of using variation and nuance in a character or two to convey that. These frontier characters end up all driving the same point, which is a contemporary view reflecting back on the past, instead of opening a window to a real time and place.I compare this movie to Hostiles, but way better than that horrid waste of time. Both had great lead actors, both were stories about traversing the west, both centered around Native/military tension, and both did an insufficient job of saying something truly meaningful (Hostiles being a miserable waste of opportunity).More could be said, but Im not trying to bag on the movie, just show why I didnt think it was great, and why nor do I consider it a real western. I want to be clear that I am not unfamiliar with the old west, it is pretty much all I do is study western characters and history. So I also dont want to ruin others fun; where I may hold too high a standard due to my familiarity, others may enjoy it for being a reasonable output for frontier history.All in all, good, not great, enjoy for what it is, and forgive it for what it isnt.

Like many other Westerns,a principal theme here is the importance of morality in bringing sanity to human life in the absence of stable authority. There is more, though: the possibility of redemption through empathy, though it is a difficult and sometimes painful path.Examples of empathy, or the lack of it, and the results thereof, abound in the story.. (Story itself is a key motif, as a key to empathy.) An unusual diversity of viewpoints is modeled, from unredeemed racism, to traumatized victims of war and oppression, to the desperate efforts of Native Americans to preserve their traditional ways of life.I will leave aside Tom Hanks' penchant for starring in roles as a messianic hero cracking wise, except to say he does it well, always a little differently each time..Special mention for the young girl playing the other leading character in a very challenging role, and for the elaborate sets depicting the wild North Texas country during Reconstruction, a critical, rarely-portrayed period of US history with clear relevance for our era.

Review title: Very well done and beautiful to watch!
Review_body: I think one of the best things this movie does is to make you really feel the emotions behind a scene, to feel the wonder of the buffalo on the great plains, the simple yet peaceful life in a small old western town, the intense fear of the protagonists trying to escape lawless men, the deep sadness of their losses, and the incredible joys they find despite it all.The director has done a wonderful job of gently guiding you through these things, taking the time to savour them before moving on. And all of this done behind the steady experience of legends like Tom Hanks and music by James Howard along with an exceptional performance by young Helena Zengel, who will undoubtedly go on to act in many more movies.All in all, a great non-traditional Western, but mostly just a great movie!Cheers!

News of the World is based upon the novel by Paulette Jiles, directed by Paul Greengrass and written by Paul Greengrass, Luke Davies. A Civil War veteran agrees to deliver a girl, taken by the Kiowa people years ago, to her aunt and uncle, against her will. They travel hundreds of miles and face grave dangers as they search for a place that either can call home. I was really excited to see again the combination between Paul Greengrass and Tom Hanks and they did not disappoint me. This is not Captain Phillips level but this is a good film. Paulette Jiles focused on storytelling and character development more than action sequences. This journey should be developed step by step and they did it perfectly. The pace is some time off but most of the time story flows perfectly. Tom Hanks and Helena Zengel's performance is top-notch. Especially great permanence from the young actress. We know about Tom Hanks, as usual, he is shining in this movie. Great cinematography. They captured beautiful lands excellently. If you're a western movie fan you are going to enjoy this movie.

I mean, it's a nice little story. It's not that dark of a story and there's points in the story that actually feel quite nice. But when there's a much better side of the same story, then what's the point?News of the World aka The Bad of Us is completely a rip-off of... *drums rollin* The Last of Us, who could've seen that one coming huh? But for real, this story isn't anything more than a rip-off of The Last of Us. I mean, this whole concept of story isn't anything special, but you can tell that the movie was trying to mimic The Last of Us and added a bit of Mandy (1952) just so that they won't get straight called out for plagiarism. And if someone says: "The movie was based on a novel", you know what, you're right kiddo. Except that novel was released in 2016. I'm not against it if you take an concept of rivarly for your movie, but at least try to make it a good movie. Unlike The Last of Us, this one ain't even good, boyo.Let's start with the acting. Helena Zengel was pretty alright with her role. I don't want to discourage her or anything, but I think she could've done a much better job. I think it might have been more of Paul Greengrass's fault but whatever. Tom Hanks was Tom Hanks and Tom Hanks as Tom Hanks is the same as Steven Seagal as Steven Seagal: uninteresting. Well, to be honest, Steven Seagal is much more interesting than Tom Hanks. I don't hate Tom Hanks, but I haven't seen him acting a character instead of himself since the early 2000s. There could've been a much more better actors for this role, but I think Tom Hanks did his job. When it comes to the other characters, well... Michael Angelo Covino did a pretty good job with his character. The other actors... did not so well with their characters.Now, the directing. I don't mean to say that Paul Greengrass is an untalented movie director who shouldn't ever try to make anything that involves good acting, good writing and good directing... but I'm saying that. I mean, sure, in Captain Phillips Barkhad Abdi was really good, but I think it's more likely that Barkhad Abdi is just a natural born actor. In Good Time he did a good job, even in Blade Runner 2049 he did a good job, so I believe that's it's more thank to him than Paul Greengrass. Paul Greengrass isn't untalented, I've seen parts of his Bourne movies and they seem actually pretty good movies, but his directing is the same as Steven Spielberg's: money-grubbin'. I don't see that there's any passion or style in the directing, it just feels like Paul Greengrass just wanted that paycheck.Cinematograpy is good. Only thing that I do like about in all of Paul Greengrass's movies, is how everything is mostly shot handheld. It's obviously a stylistic choice, which I do like, but I think it's more thanks to the cinematographer Barry Ackroyd, who shot The Hurt Locker.Music is alright. it's just alright. There's not much to say about it, to be honest. It's the most generic Hollywood violin score.Story, even though I criticized it for ripping off The Last of Us, is not the worst still. Some of the moments and dialogue are pretty well written, but mostly it's the most generic, bland, tasteless, uninteresting, boring story. There's nothing good about that, it makes the movie just more annoying to watch.Even though I criticized this movie a lot, there's still good things about it. Sadly, there were more good than bad: 4/10.

News of the World is a western-drama co-written
and directed by Paul Greengrass whom is widely known
for his collaborations in the Bourne Trilogy starring
Matt Damon. News of the World was named one
of the top-ten best films of 2020 by the National Board
of Review and it's based on the 2016 novel of the same name by Paulette Jiles. Tom Hanks delivers another satisfying performance as a Civil War Veteran who reluctantly brings it upon himself to deliver a young girl to distant relatives whom she was separated from. I haven't seen a film with this particular actor in quite some time so it was refreshing and a pleasure to witness him onscreen especially in the western genre (which I have come to favor the most). Sharing the screen is Helena Zengel who truly shines in this film as a 10-year-old named Johanna Leonberger who is unable to speak the English-language. We observe her compelling performance through her facial expressions such as her piercing eyes, and her motions are what provide communication. Separating the barrier for Captain Kidd and the audience. Truth be told, this film is very predictable and formulaic as I was able to accurately determine how this film would come to a close.But the journey was worthwhile as we witness the growing bond between these individuals who have no place to
call home and we receive a very heartwarming conclusion to the storyline. I only wish their characters and their relationship would have been fleshed out in order to grow more of an emotional attachment to them. The plot is identical to Leon: The Professional where the main character becomes the protecter of a troubled youth.The cinematography by Dariusz Wolski was absolutely gorgeous as our eyes become satiated with delicious sunsets and color grading to represent the bluish
tint of night. Overall, I believe this film is a worthy
one-time watch and I am looking forward
to viewing more projects involving these two.Follow me on Instagram: @joshuarenealvarez

Review title: News that is well Worth Viewing
Review_body: It is hard to find a film in the Tom Hanks catalogue that is not worth watching and "News", while maybe not in his Top 5 certainly ranks among his top 10.Directed and co-written by Paul Greengrass, this tale of Texas after the Civil War carries the grit and feel of a land that is wild, dirty, dusty, violent and awaiting word from the civilized world to the east that it seeks to a part of.Co-Star Helena Zengel gives a winning performance as the orphan in need of closure with her past and a pathway to a new life and a promising future.While she doesn't upstage Hanks' "Captain Kid", she holds her own with him in scene after tragic scene until the two of them make peace with their pasts and give us the happy ending that we deserved after traveling with them through the Badlands of Texas from Dallas to San Antonio.The music of James Newton Howard, the photography of Dariusz Wolski, and the editing of William Goldenberg help to weave this memorable story of the west into one that may best be viewed on a big screen with surround sound.The supporting cast of Mare Winngham, Elizabeth Marvel, Michael Covino, and Bill Camp provide us with characters rich with the language and expressions of those times.Put this on your "should see" list for a relaxing Saturday or Sunday afternoon view.

...but try this movie for yourself and do not listen to the Netflix haters on here.The story is a classic of a world-weary, grizzled older man won over by the vulnerable, yet feisty nature of a young girl. The acting, as you would expect from Hanks, is flawless and understated but it is the performance of Helena Zengal, who plays the young girl with such a sense of haunting stillness and depth, which steals the film and leaves us with the promise of a potential future star.The cinematography is beautiful, presented in HDR...which can sometimes be overly dark and shadowy...and there is none of that annoying background music which drowns out the conversation or makes your ears bleed.The film contains a good mix of tension and emotion, making It well worth the time taken to watch it.I am so very glad I did.

Review title: An Endless String Of Movie Tropes Woven Together Into One Giant Movie Cliche
Review_body: How many movies are there where a stranger becomes the unexpected guardian, protector, and hero, for a child with whom they've only recently become acquainted? A million? The movie's premise is a movie trope in and of itself. There's a suspenseful horse-and-buggy chase. Seen it a million times before. There's an Old West stand-off between an out-numbered underdog and villainous desperadoes where the underdog protagonist uses cunning and experience to outwit his antagonists. Seen it a million times before. There are numerous scenes where the unexpected guardian uses compassion and patience to break through the child's stand-offish exterior and finally establish trust between himself and the child. Seen it a million times before.There's so much cliche, that by the time anything new or interesting happens, the viewer is already bored and annoyed.In all fairness, I guess this movie shouldn't have elicited such a strong feeling of resentment in me. But given that it stars Tom Hanks, the reviews were so strong, and I had looked forward to seeing this movie for such a long time, I guess my expectations were so high, that the moment I began to get bored I became more resentful than the movie probably deserves. That being said, I was genuinely bored for long stretches of time during this movie (even during the action scenes), and it seems like that should be something difficult to accomplish for a Western starring Tom Hanks that takes place in the rural Deep South in the years immediately following the American Civil War.

Yes, we had seen these kind of plot and screenplay like 1000 times. But the backdrop of this story happens in 18th century which makes it interesting. Life style of those era people, Horses, wild west atmosphere make it kind of one time watchable.

Review title: Adds pious PC anachronisms to Jiles' beautiful story
Review_body: The child actor who plays Johanna/Cicada is astonishing, and the world or the novel is beautifully recreated in this production. The land, the scenery, the dust and dirt and hardship. That's why I enjoyed this film. However, the script adds several unnecessary right-on additions to Jiles' restrained and humane novel. Yes, we get it, racism and slavery are bad. The dispossession of the Kiowa is tragic. But this film traffics in Noble Savage stereotypes (in one episode not in the novel, the Kiowa act as a kind of deus ex machina at their own expense for the Captain and Johanna, and it's hard to sustain belief). In the novel, Kidd does not harbor Vietnam-type guilt over his participation in the Civil War on the part of the Confederacy. Why would he, in 1870? Hanks is playing the good guy archetype he always does, very competent, but at no point did I see him as a retired Confederate colonel in 1870s Texas. He acts like a Harvard professor. The film is uncomfortable with its own source material, which becomes a bit of a problem. For example, the character of Britt Johnson from Jiles' fictional universe (outlined in several of her novels) is reduced to an anonymous symbol.

There is very little new here. Guy in the west has a mission and encounters rapist, racist and the elements. There are no surprises and I found myself waiting for the movie to catch up to were I was. This film tries to deliver on emotions and tension, but the events and scenes are so predictable that you are waiting for the filmmakers to check each one off of their list of 'events' that have to happen to get to the end of the film.Director Greengrass has an issue with keeping the camera still and editing at a pace that is compatible with the film. The editing is clunky, and the camera work varies from handheld, to dolly to drones so much it feels like a YouTube review video. The B roll scenic shots are so modified that they glaringly stand out from the A footage of the actors. The whole thing is a bit of visual mess.The script, as mentioned is predictable and nothing really new is accomplished other than both Tom Hanks and Director Green Grass doing a western. They hit all the cliche messages that Hollywood require. I will say that the ending was a bit of surprise in that I assumed the worse, but it did provide a happy one. Unfortunately, it was not worth 2 hour slog to get to it.

Review title: Sweet little film, with wasted potential but great for my sleepless nights
Review_body: This film kind of disappointed me. Make no mistake, this is still a touching, warm little film about a scarred Civil War veteran (what would westerns be without those?) and a scarred little girl who don't know whether she's Indian or "white" (bless 'em). What is nice about a Tom Hanks vehicle is that you kind of know what to expect, whatever the genre: a character and a film full decency and honesty, trying to do his best in a fallen world. Hanks is often, and rightfully, compared to Jimmy Stewart, so it's nice to see him appear in a western, although this one is no John Ford masterpiece. Hanks is kind of my comfort food I guess, and seeing him in an old-fashioned western is doubly comforting. I will probably watch this film hundreds of times in my lifetime, anytime I'll feel sad or bad, wanting to crawl in a corner and be left alone with my cuddly little western.Sure, the film could have been miles more impactful in the wider world if it had remembered its own title and shown more of the newsman's job, which was a fascinating conceit to start with and is just unexplainably forgotten pretty early on (even THE POSTMAN does a better job on that front). The film also opens on some pretty dark stuff, with background elements reminding you this is Reconstruction and that the situation in this part of the country is very tense indeed. But that turns out to be only background music, and the film chooses to focus instead on adventure, mishaps, drone shots in the great outdoors and the fuzzy feelings slowly but surely developing between the two characters.Not that I'm complaining: it's a harmless, toothless film I need when I feel down and out. Otherwise I can always rewatch THE SEARCHERS, right?

Review title: Poignant, beautifully shot film that resonates today
Review_body: This is a film that captures the tragedy and resilience of America's history through the eyes of its two protagonists, one old, one young, set against the panorama of a primitive, southwestern landscape. Texas settlers and wanderers, damaged by the Civil War that ended five years earlier, and still in the shadow of the Lost Cause, are battling the elements and one another, as Native Americans are struggling to survive. Tom Hanks plays an itinerant 'news reader', a Confederate war vet who crisscrosses the state, bringing information to isolated towns. He befriends a traumatized, twice-orphaned young girl, who only speaks Kiowa, and sets out to bring her to her only surviving relatives. Unsurprisingly, they bond, but this is grounded in emotional truth and harsh reality. The 'American dream' isn't pretty, and the seeds of today's disunity can be found in the movie's journey.

Review title: A horrible adaptation of a beautiful book. A terrible disappointment.
Review_body: This movie is one of the worst adaptations of a book that I have ever seen. My wife and I listened to an audio reading of the book and then watched the move the next day. What a letdown! We wondered whether the writer and director of the movie had even bothered to read the book. The book by Paulette Jiles is a beautiful story about a 72-year old man, Captain Jefferson Kyle Kidd, an itinerant news reader in post-Civil War Texas, who agrees to take a 10-year old girl, Johanna, on a 400-mile trip, in a horse-drawn wagon, down to the San Antonio region to deliver her to her family. Johanna had been kidnapped by the Kiowa Indians four years earlier and all members of her immediate family had been killed. But she has relatives in south Texas and Captain Kidd (Tom Hanks) Is given $50 by federal officials to take Johanna to her relatives. However, Johanna wants to return to her Kiowa family, she no longer speaks English, she does not dress like young girls her age who are not living in a Native American community, and she is a strong-willed young lady. So Captain Kidd has his hands full, in trying to communicate with Johanna, in fending off a number of perils that they face during their journey, and in dealing with the vagaries of old age. The entire story is built on the relationship between Captain Kidd and Johanna. In the book, this relationship is beautifully played out. In the movie the relationship is never developed. And most of the adventures that Captain Kidd and Johanna face are missing from the movie. If the writer and Director of the movie had simply followed the story in the book, the movie would have been a beautiful production. They not only cut out important details of the story (which is inevitable when a movie is adapted from a book), but they also destroyed important premises underlying Ms. Jiles' novel. They tried to write a different story, which was trite, boring, and hard to comprehend at times. It was butchery at its best and it probably explains why the movie has not done very well at the box office. It was a great opportunity lost, to say the least. And we were very sad because we were very excited to watch the movie after reading the book. To say that we were disappointed is a great understatement. We loved the book. We loathed the movie.

Few actors can do so much with so little dialog, but Helena Zengel's outstanding performance makes this movie and should be recognized come awards season.We found bond of trust and respect and more that develops between their characters and the unspoken teamwork that saves them in so many situations with a so little common language were maybe the most important part of the film for us.The pace is leisurely, but we never found it slow. Review title: Alone in the World and Looking for a Home
Review_body: Quite simply, this is a movie about two people who want to go home but they can't because neither one of them has a home anymore. It's about being alone in the world and deciding whether you want to stay that way or make a connection with another person. It's also about how you deal with the tragic circumstances that caused you to be alone. I watched this on a plane with no preconceived ideas and this film was a beautiful gut punch on so many levels. I really think this is a movie that will last and find a larger audience in years to come because it has so much to say about the basic human condition; that on some level we all feel alone in the world and we're all looking for some place we can call home. Tom Hanks is excellent as Captain Kidd who makes a meager living going from town to town reading to illiterate small town folk the stories of the world. Hanks elevates anything he's in but what I love most about him is that he doesn't try to push the emotion of what's happening on the audience. He is simply Captain Kidd with a tragic past doing his job and now this wild stranger comes into his life. As for that stranger, Helena Zengel was the perfect choice. There is a saying in acting, "the words mean nothing" and without giving anything away, she proves that in her eyes, in her looks and in her physical reactions to what's going on. The chemistry with these two actors was off the charts and if you notice, I haven't mentioned anything about the plot? It doesn't matter!! This movie is about two people making a connection.

With names like Paul Greengrass and Tom Hanks attached to a film you can almost always expect it to be a well made and reliably entertaining film and this didn't disappoint. Unfortunately I feel like it never really exceeded these expectations though.
Greengrass is unquestionably an accomplished filmmaker and this comes across; the story is well told and nicely shot across an expansive post-civil war Texas. The restlessness and discontent that existed in the South following the war, depicted subtly and believably by Greengrass and his strong cast, is the driving force behind many of the events and challenges that Kidd (Hanks) and Leonberger (Zengel) experience throughout their journey. On the whole, these events appeared natural and the story flowed but at times it got a little bumpy. Some plot points seemed to appear out of the blue purely as a ploy to progress the characters into the required state for the next significant event. I'm fully aware this is necessary at times but occasionally it came at the expense of believability.
In essence this comes down to whether you are looking for a more realistic (in my opinion), character driven storyline or a more event driven storyline with the intention of reaching a predefined end goal. In general, films need to be event driven due to their limited running time but the trick is making them appear as character driven as possible. For the best part, News of the World achieves this but does falter at times.
Tom Hanks puts in a solid performance as Captain Jefferson Kyle Kidd, not his best but still very good. It's difficult for someone as recognisable as Hanks to truly have an audience see only the character but he has done this more effectively in recent years with Captain Phillips and Sully. On the other hand, Helena Zengel has the advantage of being virtually unknown in comparison although this shouldn't take away from her performance. She is excellent as the innocent but by no means naïve Johanna and deserving of her Golden Globe nomination.
News of the World isn't ground-breaking and felt a little formulaic at times but the story remained captivating and was an enjoyable watch thanks to its strong cast and experienced director.

Review title: I now see how the hatred of the South for wealthy Yankees began
Review_body: We liked "News of the World" a lot. It's a man's odyssey through the post-apocalyptic towns of post-Civil War Texas, making a living by reading newspapers from across the country to gatherings of those without access or ability to get the news. There's a tinge of a "True Grit" vibe (unwillingly traveling with a young girl), but the true focus is on the lonely traveller, not the child. Some parts feel like a classic exciting western, some parts feel like a character drama, and other parts subtly portray the socioeconomics of 1870's southern Texas. We see scenes that show how the hatred of Texans for Yankees goes back to Restoration, giving some unexpected empathy to some Texans, but also showing racism at its nastiest.

Review title: Not a very tight script but a nice mood
Review_body:
It's not a bad movie for a lazy Sunday evening but there were a couple of things that I found a bit disturbing.The captain and the girl encounter 3 men who want to 'buy the girl'. Just when stuff gets heated the cops intervene and take the bad guys away. I'm not sure why the bandits were taken to jail because the captain didn't tell the cops that they wanted to 'rape the girl or buy her for pleasure'. The bandits have to go the police station to fill out some papers and at early dawn the captain and the girl leave for their destination. The 3 men also leave at dawn to chase them down and get the girl. They apparently know exactly which way they were going and when they'd leave because it didn't take long for the villains to catch them...When the captain and the girl reach the Buffalo killing factory, they meet this boy who seems to be smiling a lot. He seemed to be very interested in the girl and had this 'rapy' look in his eyes. His only remaining family member was killed by the boss but it wasn't clear if he was really hurt by it or not. His character was very confusing. He made this 180° turn in the end when he shot the boss - and none of his men noticed. There was a vibe of akwardness when he left the captain and the girl. He wanted to keep travelling but the captain suggested he'd start his new life. It was a confusing scene to me. I was expecting something to happen. And it wasn't clear if the boy had good intentions or not throughout all of his scenes. Maybe the acting was just too shallow, not explored enough.Some of the FX were horrible, like the sand storm. I'm not sure if and old guy, thristy and exhausted can move around like that in a snowstorm, yelling...
Just after this scene, indians pass by. The girl talks to one of the guys and get's a horse. She forget to ask for water apparently. Something she really needed before the sand storm. We see the gang of Indians passing by. Most of them on foot so giving away a horse is quite a sacrifice. This is probably a bit of PC motivating this.These are just 3 confusing scenes to me but maybe nobody else was bothered by it...Anyway overall it isn't a bad movie. But not all of the motivations of the characters were solid tbh.If anyone agrees or disagrees, let me know. I might have missed something.

Westerns have had their time in the spotlight but as time has gone on, they've been pushed onto the side. "News of the World" isn't the stereotypical Western where there's bandits at every corner, long horse chases, bank robberies, or Clint Eastwood; but that doesn't stop it from being enjoyable.Tom Hanks has a great performance in this movie. It's not nearly as memorable or notable as Josh Baskins from "Big" or Woody from "Toy Story" but he always brings a certain charm to each movie he's in. The movie, in real simplified terms, is Tom Hanks' character Captain Kidd reacting to the situation he's put in. And Tom Hanks excels in reacting to situations he's put in.However the real star is the actress who acts opposite to Hanks; Helena Zengel. She does a fantastic job in this role. The whole time, she has this fish-out-of-water, deer-in-the-headlights look about her. Only in the final scene does her character, Johanna, smile. And once you see her smile, your whole body is washed over with relief because that one smile feels so earned. So good job to both the leads.The film is also technically proficient. With stunning wide shots and intimate close ups, you are reminded, but not bashed over the head, of classic spaghetti Westerns. The color palette is appropriately void of bright colors but never too bland to the point where you get confused where the characters are or bored at watching the movie. And finally the pacing. Sure, the movie takes a slower time getting from point A to B and some might be turned off by it. I found it tolerable but others won't. Just know what you're getting into when you buy a ticket.All in all, a good movie. Not as memorable as some of the others out there but a good watch nonetheless.

Review title: Disappointing - we can only imagine what might have been...
Review_body: It's truly unfortunate that a sensational novel that presented an honest, realistic, sensitive, and nuanced view of Texas during Reconstruction was transformed into a movie that, though entertaining, is little more than a two-bit morality play. It's hard to understand the many changes the filmmakers apparently felt compelled to make. Instead of portraying Freedman Britt Johnson as a real, live person (and possibly setting up a prequel based on Paulette Giles's The Color of Lightning), he's stripped of his lines and only shown at the end of a rope. Captain Jefferson Kyle Kidd is transformed from war-weary veteran all too aware of the powder keg he might ignite to a reformer and activist more than willing to do just that. A wagon crash is added to clumsily increase the stakes. But - no worry - mythic Native Americans are invented to appear in a dust storm and save the day. And as hard as it is to criticize an icon like Tom Hanks, he wasn't really up to the task. One can only imagine what the movie would have been like had they cast someone like a Lonesome Dove-era Robert Duvall in the lead - and trusted Jiles's powerful and thoroughly researched work.

Go see this movie. A small jewel in this world of fast paced action movies and first person shooter games.
This is a story about the America's, a multiplicity of people having settled in different parts and defending their differences. A story about a war veteran getting burdened with the task of bringing a young orphan to her uncle and aunt down south. It's about north vs south, blue vs red, immigrants vs natives, people of different cultures and home countries. In this movie everyone is lost and everyone longs for a peaceful home.
This is a story about people having to deal with the hardships of life and fate, and the hope for a better future for everybody.
A story about overcoming differences and the blossoming of unconditional love.
A slow story, to sip slowly like a glass of good red wine, to leave the mad running world behind and pace down for an hour or two. If you are open to it, this movie tells a much, much deeper story. Look and listen between the lines.
I hope that you'll enjoy it as much as I did.

I usually don't write reviews, but seeing that this great movie is getting rather low scores, I wanted to share my opinion on it:
I think that the movie is really good. It combines a great narrative with some western movie themes, which we all like - there is a little bit of action, a bit of suspense, some very colorful characters and a deep realistic down to earth atmosphere. This movie actually reminded me of Tarantino's work in westerns, but without pointless carnage. The dialogues are deep, you are really getting to know the characters and their stories. You are even learning some new languages along the way. Regarding the technical aspects in this movie, I liked the sound, ambiance and the scenic stereotypical western shots very much.
The two main actors are great and actually show a range of emotions - something, what is not always seen in every movie recently.
All in all, if you have any interest in a historical western as a movie genre, this movie is right up your alley!

Review title: Not all it's hyped as, or could have been
Review_body: Considering the advance hype and the cast and crew, I was expecting more from this one. Paid $20 to watch it at home. Fortunately I have a serviceable home theater setup, so didn't miss the undeniably beautiful cinematography. But the story felt derivative (Unforgiven, True Grit (2010)), and the characters, especially the bad guys, seemed comic book. The picture of who to like, and who to hate, was painted in garish primary colors. Ultimately the hero's travels through Texas felt like a Liberals journey through MAGA land, right down to FOX News, and it seemed the only message beyond that was "white settlers are unenlightened, stumbling along the straight and narrow, while indigenous people understand life as a circle". Don't get me wrong, I'm not offended by that message, but it's not exactly revelatory. Silly movie. But pretty.
